[[Image:Karnataka-districts-Kodagu.png|right|thumb|200px|Kodagu: home of the Kodavas shown above in the map of Karnataka,India (in orange)]]
'''Ain-manés''' are the ancestral homes of the native communities in [[Kodagu]], and have an important role in their socio-cultural traditions. Each ainmané belongs to an okka (matrilineal clan) that is identified. The traditional ainmanés of Koḍagu have a unique architectural style. Those that are still standing today generally date from about 150 to 450 years ago, and have evolved from the simple balyamanés of earlier times. Currently there are about 1720 okkas in Koḍagu (including about 1040 [[Kodava people|Kodava]], 320 Gowda and 360 okkas of other communities). Nearly 60% of them no longer have traditional ainmanés.<ref name=Ainmanes>{{cite web|title=Ainmanes|url=http://ainmanes.com/|publisher=Chinshai technologies|accessdate=1 December 2012}}</ref>
The people Kodagu are Hindus; they believe in reincarnation, revere the cow and originally worshipped the natural elements (revering the Sun, the Moon, the Earth, water and fire) and their ancestors. The reverence of various spirits in addition to the established gods of Hinduism is also part of their religion. Each village had a Bhagwathi ([[Mahalakshmi]]) temple, each lane had a snake deity and each nad(region) had an [[Ayyappa|Aiyappa]] temple. The people worshipped Mahadeva as well. Comparatively liberal in their beliefs, the consumption of soma and pork is permitted during their ceremonies (except during Kaveri Sankramana when they have to be on a vegetarian, non-alcoholic diet). However like other Hindus, the consumption of beef is strictly prohibited. They maintained sacred groves on their public village lands from ancient times, hunting was prohibited in these woods called the Devakadu. They believe in astrology as well. Generally they didn't follow idol worship but believed in nature worship.
People settlements in Coorg are in the form of Okka family groups that are scattered across agricultural and forested holdings, where traditional ainemane houses form focal meeting points in the rural landscape. It is a joint patrilineal clan with males of common ancestry. The male members of an okka share an okka name. Currently there are about 1000 okka names and families in Kodagu. Traditionally all the members of an okka lived in a large ancestral Ainemane house (ayyangada mane – House of the Elders). The emergence of townships, as such, has been a relatively recent phenomenon and many of the main towns in Kodagu are inhabited by recent migrants. This cluster of homes and property form the nucleus of a village called ur.
The spirits of departed souls who were prominent figures in the community and had done good deeds while they were alive were worshipped. These spirit gods do not have a set form of physical representation. Symbolically a piece of rock is sanctified and considered as such a spirit deity. The founder of each clan (Okka), the Guru Karana, is worshipped by the members of that particular clan. On their ancestral clan lands the have a shrine ('''Kaimada'''), which is the shrine of the clan's first ancestor (Guru Karana), where they offer prayers and obeisance. A number of weapons, made of wood or metal, are kept in the Kaimadas. The shrine is usually made of clay or wood or covered with sheet metal, and housed within a roofed structure built near the entrance to the ain-mane. Sometimes it is simply located on a platform under a sap-exuding tree near the entrance of ainemane. Some clans conduct a karana kola, a dance of the ancestral spirit during which a Malayalee migrant dresses in elaborate colourful clothing and dances in a trance and acts as an oracle. During this ceremony he is symbolically possessed by the karana, the original founder of the particular clan. In every home a lamp called '''Nellakki Deepa''' is lit in honour of the Guru Karana. The lamp in the central hall is lit by the embers of the kitchen hearth every day. Fire of the kitchen hearth is especially sacred.
On the day of '''Huttari''' (the rice harvest festival celebrated in around November–December), the whole family assembles in their ain mane (the common family house), which is decorated with flowers and green mango and banana leaves. Specific foods are prepared: thambuttu, puttari, kari and poli poli. Then the eldest member of the family hands a sickle to the head of the family and one of the women leads a procession to the paddy fields with a lit lamp in her hands. The path leading to the field is decorated. A gunshot is fired to mark the beginning of the harvest, with chanting of "Poli Poli Deva" (prosperity) by all present. Then the symbolic harvesting of the crop begins. The rice is cut and stacked and tied in odd numbers and is carried home to be offered to the gods. The younger generation then lite fire crackers and revel, symbolising prosperity. Groups of youngsters visit neighbouring houses and show off their dancing skills and are given monetary gifts. A week later, this money is pooled and the entire village celebrates a communal dinner. All family members gather for this meal.
==The Pattole Palame Connection==
The ''Pattole Palame'' was written using the Kannada script originally; it has been translated into English by [[Boverianda Nanjamma and Chinnappa]], grandchildren of [[Nadikerianda Chinnappa]], and has been published by Rupa & Co., New Delhi.<ref>{{cite web|title=Books: Pattole Palame ~ A love song to Kodagu|url=http://mulledink.blogspot.in/2012/05/books-pattole-palame-love-song-to.html|publisher=Google blogger - Aditi De|accessdate=1 December 2012}}</ref> The translators’ introduction explains: “Since the Kodava language does not have a script, he used the Kannada script that has been in vogue since the 17th century, when the Lingayat Rajas ruled Kodagu and Kannada was their court language.”
Nadikerianda Chinnappa had begun translating the work into English in 1925 but he died in 1931, before he could complete it. Chinnappa's daughter married into the Boverianda clan. His son and daughter-in-law were both teachers. Their daughter Nanjamma and Chinnappa's daughter's son, also called Chinnappa, cross-cousins, got married. Boverianda Chinnappa, an engineer with a degree from an Illinois university, and Nanjamma, a statistician who was a visiting fellow at Cambridge University in 1974, pursued their professions at Chennai, Kolkata and Canada. In the 1970s, Boverianda Chinnappa, Nanjamma's mother and Nanjamma began to copy out the Pattole Palome in longhand over almost three years.<ref name="It's story time, folks">{{cite web|title=It's story time, folks|url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2003/10/16/stories/2003101600630300.htm|publisher=The Hindu newspaper|accessdate=1 December 2012}}</ref>
While they were searching for copies of the original edition of the [[Pattole Palome]], a ninety-year-old farmer and self-taught folk artist, Bacharaniyanda Annaiah, responded to their advertisement. During his youth unable to afford the book he had copied out the entire text word by word under a kerosene lamp. This hardcover book he gifted to the Chinnappas. Nanjamma's parents assisted in translating and interpreting the text. In the second edition of ‘Pattole Palame” (or ‘Silken Lore’), published by the University of Mysore in 1975, the editor describes it as one of the earliest extensive collections of folklore from any Indian community.<ref name="It's story time, folks"/>
After retirement they settled down in Bangalore in 1995 and began to realise his cherished dream. Finally in 2003, they completed the work and it has been published by Rupa & Co., New Delhi. That same year it was released in Madikeri (Mercara). This book has become the chief text for the Coorgs.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Book Review: Pattole Palame: Kodava Culture - Folksongs and Traditions |author= M N Venkatesha|url=https://indianfolklore.org/journals/index.php/IFRJ/article/view/182/189|journal=Indian Folklore Research Journal|volume=1|issue=4|year=2004|pages=124-129|accessdate=13 September 2018}}</ref>
[[Boverianda Nanjamma and Chinnappa]] have chalked out at least ten Kodagu-based projects for the future, including a directory of aine mane or ancestral homes, a lexicon of the Kodava language and a biography of the late Bacharaniyanda Annaiah, a self-taught folk artist. Presently they have been working on the ainemane project, this can be found on the '''Ainmanes''' website.<ref name="Ainmanes"/>
==The Ainmanes Project== [[File:Nalaknad_(6).jpg|thumb|[[Nalknad Palace|Nalnad Palace]] built in the style of an Ainmane]]{{coord|12|14|34.8|N|75|42|5.8|E|region:IN|display=title}}
Boverianda Nanjamma and Chinnappa had undertaken a project to collect information regarding each and every Ainmane found in Kodagu, irrespective of the community or caste of the clan members residing in them. They visited many of them in the period between April 2003 and May 2008. They also collected oral legends and traditional information from the occupants of each of these functional Ainemanes. Along with this they also researched about the concerned clans from previously published written material, wherever possible. The information thus collected are now available on the Ainmanes website. They have also provided a glossary for the Kodava thakk words used in the site. The couple are currently working on a book “Ainmanés of Koḍagu” that will give an overview of the ancestral homes of Koḍagu and of their socio-cultural significance.
The objective of this web-site is to document the current status of the traditional ainmanés of all the communities in Koḍagu and thereby contribute to the archival records of the heritage and oralhistory of the people of Koḍagu. It provides insights into the social and religious customs and conventions of the communities in Kodagu and the way of life of the people. It will also serve to raise awareness of the value of these buildings and the need to preserve them, besides providing information for those studying the socio-cultural-architectural heritage of Kodagu.This web-site contains information on all the traditional ainmanés in Koḍagu that were functional when the Chinnappas visited them. It includes photographs and information on each ainmané and its okka. The information was collected from members of the okka present in the ainmané during the visits and from those contacted later by telephone. Where available, information was added from published articles and books.<ref name="Ainmanes"/>
Every ainmané in the web-site is identified by its mané péda, the village where it is located and the community to which it belongs. Entering the mané péda of the okka in the ‘Search window’ allows the user to retrieve the photos and information on the ainmané and the okka. A table listing the okkas visited in alphabetical order of their mané pédas along with the names of the villages where their ainmanés are located and the communities that the okkas belong to is provided. Similar tables in alphabetical order of village names and by community are also provided. Also included are sketch maps of Kodagu (in 9 sections) that show the location of each ainmané. The ainmanés are identified by numbers on the maps, and the index gives their mané pédas. A glossary gives the meanings of words in Koḍava language that are in the web-site. Accent marks in the glossary and the key to the transliteration provides a guide to the reader on the correct pronunciation of these words. The stories collected from the informants are oral narratives.<ref name="Ainmanes"/>
==Ainmanes of Kodagu (Book)== In 2014, Niyogi books has published their work titled 'Ainmanes of Kodagu'.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bopanna|first1=P T|title=KODAGU AINMANES BOOK HITS THE STANDS|url=http://www.coorgtourisminfo.com/coorg_news.php|website=Coorg Tourism Info|publisher=Bopanna|accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Ajit Gulabchand | image = Ajit Gulabchand - World Economic Forum on East Asia 2011.jpg | alt = | caption = Ajit Gulabchand at the World Economic Forum on East Asia in Jakarta, 2011 | birth_name = | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Birth-date and age|Month DD, YYYY}} --> | birth_place = [[Maharashtra]] | residence = [[Sholapur]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = [[India]]n | other_names = | occupation = [[Industrialist]] | known_for = }}
'''Ajit Gulabchand''' (born 1948)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://businesstoday.intoday.in/story/ajit-gulabchand-hcc-interview/1/186619.html|title=We create entrepreneurship against odds: HCC chief Ajit Gulabchand|date=2012-08-19|publisher=Business Today}}</ref> is an [[India]]n [[industrialist]]. Gulabchand is the [[chairman]] and [[Managing Director]] of [[Hindustan Construction Company]]. Gulabchand serves as chairman of the board of governance at [[National Institute of Construction Management and Research|National Institute of Construction Management & Research (NICMAR)]] and as chairman of [[Walchand College of Engineering]], [[Sangli]].<ref>{{Cite web| title=Web forum biography| url=http://www.weforum.org/contributors/ajit-gulabchand?fo=1}}</ref>
==Early life== Gulabchand was born to a [[Digambara]] [[Jain]] family of [[Gujarat]] settled in [[Sholapur|Solapur]] and he is the son of [[Gulabchand Hirachand]], where he possesses ancestral property.<ref>{{Cite news| title=Wine and wondering with Ajit Gulabchand| url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/the-leisure-lounge/wine-and-wondering-with-ajit-gulabchand-of-hindustan-construction/articleshow/3173736.cms | work=The Times Of India | first1=Krishna| last1=Gopalan}}</ref>
==Career== Gulabchand has been a Director of Indian a Hume Pipe since 1993. He serves as Director of Hindustan Finvest, HCC Infotech, Hincon Technoconsult, Hincon Realty, Hincon Holdings, Ucchar Investments, Western Securities, LAVASA Corporation, Motorsports Association of India, Constructmall.com, Champali Garden, Shalaka Investment, Gulabchand Foundation and as an independent, non-executive Director of [[Bajaj Electricals]].
He is a founding member of the World Economic Forum's Disaster Resource Network and a member of the National Council of Confederation of Indian Industry (CII). He is a promoter of the [[Lavasa]] township, intended to be India's first new hill station since [[Indian Independence Act 1947|independence]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/money/report_when-scribes-got-ajit-gulabchands-goat_1497514|title=When scribes got Ajit Gulabchand’s goat|date=2011-01-22|publisher=DNA India}}</ref>
== Personal life == Gulabchand is a [[kinship|scion]] of the [[Walchand Hirachand|Walchand]] family. Gulabchand took charge of Hindustan Construction Co. Ltd. after managing other large public companies promoted by the family. He also served as the Director of [[Brabourne]] Enterprises Ltd. from 25 June 1997, to 16 June 2008, and RPG Life Sciences Ltd. from 25 June 1997, to June 2008. During an interview with Newslaundry, author [[Tavleen Singh]] said that she has been living with Mr. Gulabchand for the past 25 years.
== Education == Gulabchand graduated from [[Sydenham College]], [[Mumbai University]] with a [[Bachelor's degree]] in [[commerce]].<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/beyond-business/newsmaker-ajit-gulabchand-109070300075_1.html|title=Newsmaker: Ajit Gulabchand|date=2009-07-03|newspaper=Business Standard}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} '''Alexander Leonidovich Dvorkin''' ({{lang-ru|Александр Леонидович Дворкин}}; born 20 August 1955 in [[Moscow]]) is a Russian [[medieval historian]], [[Eastern Orthodox theology|orthodox theologian]] and [[Anti-cult movement|anti-cult activist]].
==Biography== Dvorkin was born in Moscow. He received his secondary education at schools No. 25, 91 and 112 in Moscow. After graduation from grade 10, in 1972, he entered the [[Moscow State Pedagogical University|Moscow Pedagogical Institute]] at the Faculty of Russian Language and Literature. During his studies he joined the hippy movement. Dvorkin sets out two completely different versions of deductions from the institute. According to the book "Teachers and lessons: memories, stories, reflections" ({{lang-ru|"Учителя и уроки: воспоминания, рассказы, размышления"}}), together with the like-minded people, he prepared a work that was demonstrated on September 20, 1975 at an exhibition of avant-garde artists in one of the pavilions of the [[VDNKh (Russia)|VDNKh]]; about this work and its authors — a group of hippies called "Hair", to which Alexander Dvorkin was close, — American magazine "Time" positively responded; as a consequence, in the autumn of 1975, Alexander Dvorkin was expelled from the third year of the institute "for believers incompatible with those that should be in the future Soviet teacher"<ref>{{cite book |title=Учителя и уроки: воспоминания, рассказы, размышления |author=Дворкин А. Л. |page=373 |year=2008 |publisher=Христианская б-ка |isbn=5-88213-081-6 }}</ref>. According to the book "My America" ({{lang-ru|"Моя Америка"}}), he was not admitted to the fifth examination session and was expelled from the institute for poor academic performance and non-attendance in early 1975<ref>{{cite book |title=Моя Америка: автобиографический роман в двух книгах с прологом и двумя эпилогами |author=Дворкин А. Л. |page=795 |year=2013 |publisher=Христианская б-ка |isbn=978-5-905472-11-4 }}</ref>. March 6, 1977 Dvorkin emigrated from the USSR on an Israeli visa. He did not go to Israel, but went to the USA. He worked as a courier, waiter, copyist. In 1978, Dvorkin became a student at the [[Hunter College]], where he continued to study Russian literature. Dvorkin was baptized in the New York church of Christ the Savior of the Orthodox Church in America on January 19, 1980. Dvorkin graduated as Bachelor of Arts in Russian Literature in 1980 at [[Hunter College]] in 1980. In 1980, he became a student of the St. Vladimir Orthodox Theological Seminary of the OCA in New York. Dvorkin graduated as [[Master of Divinity]] in 1983 at the [[Saint Vladimir's Orthodox Theological Seminary]] in [[Crestwood, New York]]. In 1984, Dvorkin received American citizenship. In 1984, he enrolled in doctoral studies at the Department of Medieval History at [[Association of Jesuit Colleges and Universities|Jesuit-affiliated]] [[independent school]] — [[Fordham University]]. Dvorkin graduated as [[Doctor of Philosophy]] in [[Medieval studies]] in 1988 at [[Fordham University]] (thesis "Ivan the Terrible as a Religious Type"; his mentor was [[John Meyendorff]]). In late 1988, Dvorkin moved to [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]], where he worked at the bureau of the [[Voice of America]] radio station. At the same time, he became the subdeacon and [[altar server]] of bishop [[:ru:Василий (Родзянко)|Vasily Rodzianko]] in the Washington [[St. Nicholas Cathedral (Washington, D.C.)|St. Nicholas Cathedral]]. In 1991, Dvorkin moved to Germany and started working for [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|Radio Liberty]]. December 31, 1991 Dvorkin returned to Russia. He has appeared countless times on Russian television and many times on television in various Eastern-European countries.<ref>[http://rutube.ru/tracks/1848731.html For example his appearance in TV-program "National Interest"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110119042020/http://rutube.ru/tracks/1848731.html |date=19 January 2011 }}</ref> He has authored 16 books (on various cults, on Church history as well as autobiographical prose) and edited 3 more. The number of his publications and interviews (translated into 16 languages) exceeds 1000.
He is president of the Saint Ireneus of Lyons Informational Consultative Center,<ref>{{cite book |title=Religion, morality, and community in post-Soviet societies |authorlink=Mark D. Steinberg |last=Steinberg |first=Mark D. |author2=Catherine Wanner |page=300 |year=2008 |publisher=[[Indiana University Press]] |isbn=978-0-253-22038-7 }}</ref> an anti-cult organisation registered in the [[Russian Federation]] as non-religious [[NGO]], and since 2009 Vice-President of the [[European Federation of Centres of Research and Information on Sectarianism]] (FECRIS), an umbrella organization for anti-cult groups in Europe.<ref name="FECase">[[Régis Dericquebourg]], [http://www.hrwf.net/images/reports/2012/2012fecrisbook.pdf "FECRIS: European Federation of Research and Information Centers on Sectarianism"], in ''Freedom of Religion or Belief — Anti-Sect Movements and State Neutrality — A Case Study: FECRIS'', special issue of ''Religion – Staat – Gesellschaft: Zeitschrift für Glaubensformen und Weltanschauungen'' (''Journal for the Study of Beliefs and Worldviews'', {{ISSN|1438-955X}}), 2012/2, p.188–189, {{ISBN|978-3-643-99864-4}}</ref> Dvorkin is on the board of the Europe-wide counter-cult agency FECRIS. He is a professor of Church History and Cultic Studies at [[Saint Tikhon's Orthodox University]], Moscow, Russia.
==Anti-cult activism== In 1993, with the blessing of [[Alexy II of Moscow|Patriarch Alexy II]], he established a Russian anti-cult organization currently called Association of Centres for the Study of Religions and Sects (RATsIRS). From that time on he has been extremely active in opposing cults and new religious movements through his publications.<ref name="FECase" />
Dvorkin is a critic of [[Scientology]], which he regards as a dangerous cult. Church of Scientology-affiliated organizations describe him as an "anti-religious extremist", and compile negative information about him on their websites. In 1997, Scientology and several other [[new religious movement]]s sued Dvorkin and the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] for defamation, but their case was dismissed.<ref>{{cite book |title=Chercheurs de dieux dans l'espace public |last=Côté |first=Pauline |pages=157–158 |year=2001 |publisher=[[University of Ottawa Press]] |isbn=978-2-7603-0535-9 }}</ref>
Dvorkin has claimed that the followers of [[Nikolai Rerikh]] as well as Jehovah's Witnesses, Scientology, Hare Krishnas, Neo-Pagans, Neo-Pentecostals, and many others are "totalitarian cults".<ref name="Открытое письмо">{{cite journal|last=Савенко|first=Юрий|script-title=ru:Открытое письмо Президенту Российской Федерации Д.А. Медведеву|journal=[[Nezavisimiy Psikhiatricheskiy Zhurnal]]|year=2009|issue=№ 2|pages=5–6|url=http://www.npar.ru/journal/2009/2/medved.htm|accessdate=12 July 2011|language=ru}}</ref> "When a psychiatrist-academician (Dmitrieva, Sidorov) or an expert-psychologist of the Institute of Psychology of the Russian Academy of Sciences rely on the works by Dvorkin and [[Steven Hassan|Hassan]], which do not belong to science, it is a symptom of degradation", said [[Yuri Savenko]], the President of the [[Independent Psychiatric Association of Russia]].<ref name="Отчетный доклад">{{cite journal|last=Савенко|first=Юрий|script-title=ru:Отчетный доклад о деятельности НПА России за 2000-2003 гг.|journal=[[Nezavisimiy Psikhiatricheskiy Zhurnal]]|year=2004|issue=№ 2|pages=|url=http://www.npar.ru/journal/2004/2/summary.htm|accessdate=1 January 2012|issn=1028-8554|language=ru}}</ref>
Dvorkin supports himself and his family by teaching, but dedicates at least half of his working time to helping those harmed by cults. He travels regularly throughout Russia and Eastern Europe, running seminars and conferences.

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Andrew Huang | image = Bunnie portrait cropped screenres.jpg | alt = Andrew Huang | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1975}} | birth_place = [[Kalamazoo, Michigan]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Singapore]] | nationality = [[United States|American]] | other_names = bunnie | alma_mater = [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] | occupation = Hacker, author, researcher | known_for = [[Chumby]], ''Hacking the Xbox'', [[Novena (computing platform)|Novena]] | website = https://www.bunniestudios.com/ }} '''Andrew "bunnie" Huang''' (born 1975) is an American researcher and [[Hacker (programmer subculture)|hacker]],<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2016/09/30/green_asks_protection_from_dmca_lawsuits/|title=Crypto guru Matt Green asks courts for DMCA force field so he can safely write a textbook|last=Thomson|first=Iain|date=30 September 2016|website=[[The Register]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-10-09|last2=Apple}}</ref> who holds a Ph.D in [[electrical engineering]] from [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] and is the author of the freely available 2003 book ''Hacking the Xbox: An Introduction to Reverse Engineering''. As of 2012 he resides in [[Singapore]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dangerousprototypes.com/2012/08/23/workshop-video-36-beers-in-bunnies-workshop/|title=Workshop Video #36: Beers in Bunnie’s Workshop|last=Lesnet|first=Ian|date=2012-08-23|website=Dangerous Prototypes|publisher=|access-date=|author=|accessdate=2014-03-16}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Huang attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1992, earning a Ph.D in electrical engineering in 2002.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://makezine.com/2012/04/30/makes-exclusive-interview-with-andrew-bunnie-huang-the-end-of-chumby-new-adventures/|title=MAKE's Exclusive Interview with Andrew (bunnie) Huang - The End of Chumby, New Adventures {{!}} Make:|last=Torrone|first=Phillip|date=2012-04-30|website=[[Make (magazine)|Make]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-06-09}}</ref> He stated that he had 'flipped a coin' to determine whether to pursue biology or electronics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theblueprint.com/stories/andrew-huang/|title=An interview with Andrew Huang|last=|first=|date=|website=The Blueprint|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-09}}</ref> Huang is also a member of the [[Zeta Beta Tau]] fraternity.
The nickname bunnie is short for vorpalbunnie, a reference to the creature in both [[Monty Python and the Holy Grail]] and [[Moria (video game)|Moria]], that he used as a [[Bulletin board system|BBS]] screen name.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://features.slashdot.org/story/14/08/21/0334254/interviews-andrew-bunnie-huang-answers-your-questions|title=Interviews: Andrew "bunnie" Huang Answers Your Questions - Slashdot|last=|first=|date=|website=[[Slashdot]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-06-09}}</ref>
== Projects == Huang was the hardware lead at [[Chumby]]; his responsibilities included the design and production of Chumby devices, as well as the strategic planning and ecosystem development of the broader Chumby hardware platform.
He has completed several major projects, ranging from hacking the [[Xbox]], to designing the world's first fully integrated photonic-silicon chips running at 10 Gbit/s with [[Luxtera|Luxtera, Inc.]], to building some of the first prototype hardware for silicon nanowire device research with Caltech. Huang has also participated in the design of [[wireless]] transceivers for use in [[802.11b]] and [[Bluetooth]] networks with [[Mobilian Corporation|Mobilian]], graphics chips at Silicon Graphics, [[digital cinema]] [[codec]]s at [[Qualcomm]], and autonomous robotic submarines during the 1999 competition held by the [[Association for Unmanned Vehicle Systems International|AUVSI]] that the MIT team won. He is also responsible for the "un-design" of many security systems, with an appetite for the challenge of digesting silicon-based hardware security.<ref name=":0" />
Huang was scheduled to appear as an [[expert witness]] in the trial [[United States v. Crippen]] to determine whether or not [[modding]] an [[Xbox]] violates sections of the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act|DMCA]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Kravets|first=David|title=Threat Level Privacy, Crime and Security Online Previous post Next post Prosecutors Seek to Block Xbox Hacking Pioneer From Trial|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2010/10/xbox-modder-tria/|accessdate=May 1, 2011|newspaper=Wired|date=October 21, 2010}}</ref> The case was dropped suddenly on the third day of trial before the [[jury]] sat by the US federal authorities who had initiated the action.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kravets|first=David|title=Prosecutors Dismiss Xbox-Modding Case Mid-Trial|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2010/12/crippen-dismissed/|accessdate=May 1, 2011|newspaper=Wired|date=December 2, 2010}}</ref> The case was dismissed before Huang was called to give testimony.
He also created the [[open hardware]] Safecast Geiger Counter Reference Design, as a volunteer effort in response to the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake]], [[tsunami]], and ensuing [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster|meltdown of Fukushima Daiichi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boingboing.net/2012/03/15/bunnie-huangs-open-geiger-co.html|title=Bunnie Huang's open Geiger counter: design notes and reference|last=Doctorow|first=Cory|date=2012-03-15|website=|publisher=[[Boing Boing]]|access-date=|author=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://geigercounter.com/soul-geiger-counter/|title=Inside the Heart and Soul of a new Geiger counter|last=Sythe|first=Dan|date=2012-09-27|website=|publisher=Geiger Counter Bulletin|access-date=|author=}}</ref> A project in collaboration with Jie Qi of the [[MIT Media Lab]] is Circuit Stickers, a peel-and-stick circuit system for crafting electronics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crowdsupply.com/chibitronics/circuit-stickers|title=Circuit Stickers|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Crowd Supply|access-date=|author=Chibitronics}}</ref> Huang was interviewed on [[David L. Jones (electronics engineer)|Dave Jones]]' ''The Amp Hour'' in episode #84, where he talked about his electronics work in China and reverse engineering.<ref name="AmpHourInterview">{{cite web|url=http://www.theamphour.com/the-amp-hour-84-bunnies-bibelot-bonification/|title=The Amp Hour #84 - An Interview with Bunnie Huang - Bunnie's Bibelot Bonification|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=|work=The Amp Hour|accessdate=22 December 2013}}</ref>
Huang is a member of the advisory board for [[Crowd Supply]], the crowdfunding platform that he used for [[Novena_(computing_platform)|Novena]] and ''The Essential Guide to Electronics in Shenzhen.''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crowdsupply.com/launch|title=Launch|last=|first=|date=|website=Crowd Supply|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-02}}</ref>
=== Reverse engineering === Huang has a long and noted history with the [[reverse engineering]] and [[Hacking of consumer electronics|hacking of consumer products]]. His 2003 publication ''Hacking the [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]]: An Introduction to Reverse Engineering'' was one of the first published works regarding the reverse engineering of a high end consumer product. He faced significant legal pressure from [[Microsoft]] to not reveal the details of his exploits, and the book itself reveals that he had received a letter from [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]], where he was at the time a student, informing him of their disavowal of any association with his project. Additionally, his publisher [[John Wiley & Sons]] had rescinded their intent to publish the book.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://cryptome.org/2013/03/hacking-digital-dissidence.pdf|title=Resistance, Liberation Technology and Human Rights in the Digital Age|last=Ziccardi|first=Giovanni|publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media]]|year=2012|isbn=|location=|pages=110}}</ref>
[[File:Decapsulated microSD memory card lineup-genuine, questionable, and fake-counterfeit.jpg|thumb|microSD cards: genuine & questionable]]
In part because of this response by MIT to his work, when the Institute was again put at the forefront of controversy in their handling of the criminal prosecution brought against [[Aaron Swartz]], and his subsequent suicide, Huang released the book for free through [[No Starch Press]], remarking that "Without the right to tinker and explore, we risk becoming enslaved by technology; and the more we exercise the right to hack, the harder it will be to take that right away".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.slashgear.com/xbox-hacker-bunnie-huang-makes-book-free-in-aaron-swartz-tribute-11273285/|title=Xbox hacker “bunnie” Huang makes book free in Aaron Swartz tribute|date=2013-03-11|website=SlashGear|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nostarch.com/xboxfree|title=An open letter from bunnie, author of Hacking the Xbox|last=Huang|first=Andrew|date=March 2013|website=[[No Starch Press]]|publisher=|access-date=2016-06-09}}</ref>
In 2005, Huang worked with a team from the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] to develop code that interprets [[printer steganography]] markings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://w2.eff.org/Privacy/printers/docucolor/|title=DocuColor Tracking Dot Decoding Guide|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=[[Electronic Frontier Foundation]]|access-date=|accessdate=2015-12-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114074339/https://w2.eff.org/Privacy/printers/docucolor/|archive-date=January 14, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Huang created the NeTV in 2011, which was the first known public use of the [[High-bandwidth Digital Content Protection|High-bandwidth Digital Content Protection (HDCP)]] 'master key'. The device uses the master key to implement a video overlay on existing HDCP-protected links, in a fashion which purportedly does not violate the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act|DMCA]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/09/16/chumby_nettv_hack/|title=How gizmo maker's hack outflanked copyright trolls|last=Goodin|first=Dan|date=September 16, 2011|work=|newspaper=[[The Register]]|access-date=|via=|accessdate=September 17, 2011}}</ref> Both the hardware and [[firmware]] for the NeTV are openly available under the [[CC-BY-SA]] license.<ref>Source code links at http://kosagi.com/w/index.php?title=NeTV_Main_Page</ref>
He has also used reverse engineering techniques to reveal why certain [[MicroSD]] cards are poor in quality.<ref>{{cite news|last=Doctorow|first=Cory|title=Sleuthing uncovers the mystery of Kingston MicroSD cards' crappy QA|url=http://boingboing.net/2010/02/16/sleuthing-uncovers-t.html|accessdate=May 1, 2011|newspaper=Boing Boing|date=Feb 16, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bunniestudios.com/blog/?page_id=1022|title=On MicroSD Problems|last=Huang|first=Andrew|date=|work=|newspaper=bunnie's blog|access-date=|via=|accessdate=}}</ref> In 2013, he presented results in collaboration with fellow Singapore developer Sean 'xobs' Cross revealing methods to load arbitrary code into microSD cards via [[Backdoor (computing)|backdoors]] built into the [[embedded controller]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Exploration and Exploitation of an SD Memory Card|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CPEzLNh5YIo|date=2013-12-29|author=bunnie and xobs|publisher=30c3 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140710051319/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CPEzLNh5YIo |archive-date=2014-07-10 |dead-url=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bunniestudios.com/blog/?page_id=3592|title=On Hacking MicroSD Cards|last=Huang|first=Andrew|date=|work=|newspaper=bunnie's blog|access-date=|via=|accessdate=}}</ref>
On 21 July 2016, Huang and [[Edward Snowden]], in a talk at [[MIT Media Lab]]’s Forbidden Research event, published research for a smartphone case, the so-called ''Introspection Engine'', that would monitor signals received and sent by that phone to provide an alert to the user if their phone is [[Cellphone surveillance|transmitting or receiving information when it shouldn't be]] (for example when it's turned off or in airplane mode), a feature described by Snowden to be useful for journalists or activists operating under hostile governments that would otherwise track their activities through their phones.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pubpub.org/pub/direct-radio-introspection|title=Against the Law: Countering Lawful Abuses of Digital Surveillance|last=Snowden|first=Edward|last2=Huang|first2=Andrew (bunnie)|date=2016-07-21|website=|publisher=PubPub|access-date=2016-08-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/2016/07/21/edward-snowdens-new-research-aims-to-keep-smartphones-from-betraying-their-owners/|title=Edward Snowden’s New Research Aims to Keep Smartphones From Betraying Their Owners|last=Lee|first=Micah|date=2016-07-21|website=The Intercept|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/07/snowden-designs-device-warn-iphones-radio-snitches/|title=Snowden Designs a Device to Warn if Your iPhone’s Radios Are Snitching|last=Greenberg|first=Andy|date=|website=|publisher=Wired|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/jul/21/phone-case-privacy-data-monitor-bluetooth-wifi-snowden-introspection-engine|title=Edward Snowden designs phone case to show when data is being monitored|last=Mott|first=Nathaniel|date=2016-07-21|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-08-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2016/07/22/edward-snowden-co-designs-an-iphone-case-that-alerts-user-to-sur/|title=Edward Snowden co-designs an iPhone case that alerts user to surveillance activity|last=Palazzo|first=Chiara|date=|website=|publisher=The Telegraph|access-date=2016-08-07}}</ref>
=== Novena === [[File:Novena laptop motherboard.jpg|thumb|The [[open-source hardware]] laptop motherboard, [[Novena (computing platform)|Novena]].]]In 2013, Huang announced that he, again in collaboration with Cross, was at work developing a [[laptop]] called the [[Novena (computing platform)|''Novena'']]. The laptop is the first of its kind, in that the hardware and software are entirely [[Open-source model|open]] and only include components where the manufacturing companies do not require [[non-disclosure agreements]] to obtain the documentation necessary for design.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://makezine.com/magazine/make-38-cameras-and-av/building-an-open-source-laptop/ |title=Building an Open Source Laptop |author=Bunnie Huang |date=2014-01-08 |publisher=Makezine |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140316080440/http://makezine.com/magazine/make-38-cameras-and-av/building-an-open-source-laptop/ |archivedate=March 16, 2014 }}</ref> In addition to the normal laptop components, the ''Novena'' motherboard also includes an [[Field-programmable gate array|FPGA]], dual Ethernet ports, a three-axis [[accelerometer]], and easily augmentable hardware.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.kosagi.com/w/index.php?title=Novena_Main_Page | title = Novena Main Page | author = bunnie | date = 2014-03-14 }}</ref> On May 7, 2014 the Novena's [[crowdfunding]] campaign reached its goal of $250,000 and went on to raise a total of $722,880 without taking subsequent pre-orders into account.
=== Writing === Huang is a contributing writer for [[Make (magazine)|MAKE magazine]], as well as being a member of their technical advisory board. He has also written for [[Gizmodo]] and [[IEEE Spectrum]].
He has also written extensively about [[Electronics industry in China|manufacturing in China]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Doctorow|first=Cory|title=Bunnie Huang's blog-series on Chinese manufacturing|url=http://boingboing.net/2007/07/13/bunnie_huangs_blogse.html|accessdate=May 2, 2011|newspaper=Boing Boing|date=July 13, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/why-its-easier-to-innovate-in-china-than-in-the-united-1709911838|title=Why It's Often Easier To Innovate In China Than In The United States|last=Huang|first=Andrew 'bunnie'|website=Gizmodo|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-09}}</ref> In March 2016, Huang successfully completed the crowdfunding campaign for his book ''The Essential Guide to Electronics in Shenzhen'', a manual written to enable the English speaking electronics community to be able to navigate [[China]]'s [[Huaqiangbei]] marketplace in [[Shenzhen]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://boingboing.net/2016/02/04/bunnie-huangs-essential-gu.html|title=Bunnie Huang's "Essential Guide to Electronics in Shenzhen"|date=2016-02-04|website=Boing Boing|access-date=2016-06-08}}</ref> widely regarded as one of the world's premier electronics marketplaces and production hubs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/gallery/2014/jun/13/huaqiangbei-shenzhen-market-smartphone-parts-in-pictures|title=Huaqiangbei: the mega market with every smartphone part – in pictures|last=Arthur|first=Charles|date=2014-06-13|website=the Guardian|access-date=2016-06-09}}</ref> He also appeared in [[Wired (magazine)|Wired's]] 2016 documentary ''Inside Shenzhen: The Silicon Valley of hardware.''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/shenzhen-silicon-valley-of-hardware-wired-documentary|title=Inside Shenzhen: The Silicon Valley of hardware|last=Reynolds|first=Matthew|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-08-26}}</ref>
=== DMCA Lawsuit ===
In July 2016, Huang became a plaintiff in a lawsuit filed by the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] (EFF) that challenges the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA). In the complaint, the EFF argue on behalf of Huang (and his company AlphaMax LLC.) that the "anti-circumvention" and "anti-trafficking" provisions of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act threaten free speech.<ref>{{cite web|title=EFF Lawsuit Takes on DMCA Section 1201: Research and Technology Restrictions Violate the First Amendment|url=https://www.eff.org/press/releases/eff-lawsuit-takes-dmca-section-1201-research-and-technology-restrictions-violate|website=Electronic Frontier Foundation|accessdate=21 July 2016}}</ref><ref name=":1" />
== Awards == In 2007, Huang received the Lewis Winner award for Best paper at ISSCC 2006 (A 10Gbit/s photonic modulator and WDM MUX/DEMUX integrated with electronics in 0.13 um SOI CMOS, Solid-State Circuits Conference, 2006. ISSCC 2006. Digest of Technical Papers. IEEE International)<ref>{{cite web | url = http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?arnumber=04242253 | title = ISSCC 2007 / Session 1 / Plenary Awards | publisher = IEEE | date = 2007-02-12 }}</ref>
In September 2012, Huang received the 2012 [[EFF Pioneer Award]] for his work in hardware hacking, open source and activism.<ref>{{cite pressrelease | url = https://www.eff.org/press/releases/hardware-hacker-anti-acta-activist-and-groundbreaking-anonymity-group-win-eff-pioneer | title = Hardware Hacker, Anti-ACTA Activist, and Groundbreaking Anonymity Group Win EFF Pioneer Awards | date = 2012-09-27 | publisher = [[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]] }}</ref>

'''Anne King''' (c. 1688/9 - 1 Jul 1767)<ref name=":0">Lemmings, D. (2008, January 03). King, Peter, first Baron King (1669–1734), lord chancellor. ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.'' Ed. Retrieved 24 Nov. 2018, from <nowiki>http://0-www.oxforddnb.com.catalogue.wellcomelibrary.org/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-15582</nowiki>.</ref> was an English aristocrat and philanthropist.
Anne was the daughter of Richard Seys (or Seyes) of Boverton Court, [[Glamorgan]], [[Wales]]<ref name=":1">Mosley, Charles, editor. ''Burke's Peerage, Baronetage & Knightage, 107th edition, 3 volumes''. Wilmington, Delaware, U.S.A.: Burke's Peerage (Genealogical Books) Ltd, 2003, p. 2416.</ref>, whose fortune was estimated to be at least £4000 on the occasion of her marriage.<ref name=":0" />
She married Peter King, a lawyer and politician who would later be made [[Peter King, 1st Baron King|1st Baron King]], in September 1704.<ref name=":0" /> The couple had six children together, and four of their sons would accede to their father's Barony:
# Hon. Elizabeth King # Hon. Ann King # [[John King, 2nd Baron King|John King, 2nd Lord King, Baron of Ockham]] (13 Jan 1706 - 10 Feb 1740) # [[Peter King, 3rd Baron King|Peter King, 3rd Lord King, Baron of Ockham]] (13 Mar 1708/9 - 22 Mar 1754) # [[William King, 4th Baron King|William King, 4th Lord King, Baron of Ockham]] (15 Apr 1711 - 16 Apr 1767) # [[Thomas King, 5th Baron King|Thomas King, 5th Lord King, Baron of Ockham]] (19 Mar 1712 - 4 Apr 1779)
The family home was at [[Ockham, Surrey]], where Anne's husband would be buried after his death on 22 July 1734, the result of a series of strokes.<ref name=":0" />
She was one of the [[Signatories to the Ladies' Petition for the Establishment of the Foundling Hospital|signatories]] to [[Thomas Coram|Thomas Coram's]] petition to [[George II of Great Britain|King George II]] to establish the [[Foundling Hospital]]. She signed on 21 January 1735.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/53361054|title=Thomas Coram, Gent., 1668-1751|last=Gillian.|first=Wagner,|date=2004|publisher=The Boydell Press|year=|isbn=1843830574|location=Woodbridge, Suffolk|pages=199|oclc=53361054}}</ref>
She died on 1 July 1767.<ref name=":1" />

|15 December 1978|2000|reason=div}} }} | alma_mater = [[Jesus College, Cambridge]] | children = {{plain list| * Polly Higson * [[David Armstrong-Jones, 2nd Earl of Snowdon]] * [[Lady Sarah Chatto]] * Lady Frances von Hofmannsthal * Jasper Cable-Alexander }} | parents = {{plain list| * [[Ronald Armstrong-Jones]] * [[Anne Parsons, Countess of Rosse|Anne Messel]] }} }} '''Antony Charles Robert Armstrong-Jones, 1st Earl of Snowdon''', {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|FRSA|GCVO|RDI}} (7 March 1930{{snd}}13 January 2017), commonly known as '''Lord Snowdon''', was a British photographer and film-maker. He was the husband of [[Princess Margaret]] and brother-in-law of [[Queen Elizabeth II]]. == Early life == Armstrong-Jones was the only son from the marriage of the [[barrister]] [[Ronald Armstrong-Jones]] (1899–1966) and his first wife [[Anne Parsons, Countess of Rosse|Anne Messel]] (later Countess of Rosse; 1902–1992). He was born at Eaton Terrace, [[Belgravia]], in London.{{cite web|last=Rayner |first=Gordon |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/2080154/Lord-Snowdon-Antony-Charles-Robert-Armstrong-Jones-1st-Earl-of-Snowdon.html |title=Lord Snowdon: Antony Charles Robert Armstrong-Jones, 1st Earl of Snowdon |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=5 June 2008 |accessdate=14 July 2017}} He was called "Tony" by his close relatives.Hutchinson, Roger & Gary Kahn. ''A Family Affair: The Margaret and Tony Story'' (Two Continents, 1977)Brown, Craig. ''Hello Goodbye Hello: A Circle of 101 Remarkable Meetings'' (Simon and Schuster, 2013) [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=jVZoAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA285 p. 285]Geld, Ellen Bromfield. ''View from the Fazenda: A Tale of the Brazilian Heartlands'' (Ohio University Press, 2003) [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ACly62fZ3xEC&pg=PA158 p. 158] Armstrong-Jones's paternal grandfather was [[Robert Armstrong-Jones|Sir Robert Armstrong-Jones]], the British psychiatrist and physician.{{cite web|last1=Marco|first1=Neil|title=An Historic Home|url=http://www.plasdinas.co.uk/about/historic-home/|publisher=infoplasdinas@.co.uk|accessdate=8 June 2015|quote=In 1899 Sir Robert Jones, who subsequently altered his name to Armstrong-Jones, had a son named Ronald. The family was, at that time, living in the London area and retained Plas Dinas as their country home. Sir Ronald Jones married Anne, and the marriage produced a son, Antony, who in 1961 [sic] married HRH Princess Margaret, the Queen's sister.}} His paternal grandmother, Margaret Armstrong-Jones (née Roberts), was the daughter of [[Owen Roberts (educator)|Sir Owen Roberts]], the Welsh educationalist.{{cite web|title=Nobility in Tony's Background|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1960/04/28/page/35/article/nobility-in-tonys-background|publisher=Chicago Tribune 28 April 1960|quote=...Margaret was the daughter of Sir Owen Roberts|accessdate=1 January 2015}} A maternal uncle was [[Oliver Messel]] (1904–1978) and a maternal great-grandfather was the ''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]'' cartoonist [[Edward Linley Sambourne|Linley Sambourne]] (1844–1910), and his great-great-uncle [[Alfred Messel]] was a well-known Berlin architect.{{cite web | url = https://www.rbkc.gov.uk/subsites/museums/18staffordterrace/historycollections/thesambournefamily.aspx | title = The Sambourne family | publisher = Borough of Kensington and Chelsea | accessdate = 13 January 2017}} Additionally, his great-great-grandmother, Frances Linley, was a first cousin of [[Elizabeth Linley]], wife of [[Richard Brinsley Sheridan]].{{cite book|last1=Cathcart|first1=Helen|title=Lord Snowdon|date=1968|publisher=W.H. Allen|location=London|isbn=978-0491003810|page=13}} Armstrong-Jones's parents divorced in 1935 when he was five years old.{{cite book|last1=Cathcart|first1=Helen|title=Lord Snowdon|date=1968|publisher=W.H. Allen|location=London|isbn=978-0491003810|page=52}} As a schoolboy he contracted [[polio]] while on holiday at their country home in [[Wales]]. During the six months that he was in [[Liverpool Royal Infirmary]] recuperating, his only family visits were from his sister Susan.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/non_fictionreviews/3554322/Lord-Snowdon-small-in-stature-big-in-bed.html "''Snowdon: the Biography'' by [[Anne de Courcy]], reviewed by Duncan Fallowell"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. 20 June 2008. == Education == Armstrong-Jones was educated at two [[Independent school (United Kingdom)|independent boarding schools]]: firstly at [[Sandroyd School]]{{cite book|last1=Cathcart|first1=Helen|title=Lord Snowdon|date=1968|publisher=W.H. Allen|location=London|isbn=978-0491003810|page=60}} in [[Wiltshire]] from the autumn term of 1938 to 1943. Armstrong-Jones attended [[Eton College]], beginning in the [[Michaelmas]] term of 1943.{{cite book|last1=Cathcart|first1=Helen|title=Lord Snowdon|date=1968|publisher=W.H. Allen|location=London|page=65}} In March 1945, he qualified in the "extra special weight" class of the School Boxing Finals.{{cite book|last1=Cathcart|first1=Helen|title=Lord Snowdon|date=1968|publisher=W.H. Allen|location=London|pages=73–74}} He continued to box in 1946, gaining at least two flattering mentions in the ''Eton College Chronicle''.{{cite web|last1=Coco|first1=Tatiana|title=Lord Snowdon by Helen Cathcart, Chapter 4|url=http://tatianacressidacoco.blogspot.com/2017/11/sambournelinleylives.html|accessdate=22 November 2017}} While on holiday at his father's family estate in [[North Wales]] (Plas Dinas), he was stricken with [[poliomyelitis]].{{cite book|last1=Cathcart|first1=Helen|title=Lord Snowdon|date=November 1968|publisher=W.H. Allen/Virgin Books|location=London|isbn=978-0491003810|page=69}} In 1947, he was a coxswain in Eton's traditional "Fourth of June" Daylight Procession of Boats. He then matriculated at [[Jesus College, Cambridge]], where he studied architecture but failed his second-year exams.{{cite news|title=Lord Snowdon dies aged 86|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-38611497|accessdate=18 January 2017|work=''BBC News''|date=13 January 2017}} He [[coxswain (rowing)|coxed]] the winning [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge boat]] in the [[The Boat Race 1950|1950 Boat Race]].British Rowing Almanack 1950. == Life and career == [[File:Earlofsnowdon.jpeg|thumb|left|Armstrong-Jones in 1958, photographed by [[Carl Van Vechten]]]] After university, Armstrong-Jones began a career as a photographer in fashion, design and theatre. His stepmother had a friend who knew [[Baron (photographer)|Baron the photographer]]; Baron visited Armstrong-Jones in his London flat, which doubled as his work studio.{{cite book|last1=Cathcart|first1=Helen|title=Lord Snowdon|date=1968|publisher=W.H. Allen|location=London|page=82|edition=Hardback}} Baron, impressed, agreed to bring on Armstrong-Jones as an apprentice, first on a fee-paying basis but eventually, as his talent and skills became apparent to Baron, as a salaried associate.{{cite book|last1=Cathcart|first1=Helen|title=Lord Snowdon|date=1968|publisher=W.H. Allen|location=London|page=84|edition=Hardback}} Much of his early commissions were theatrical portraits, often with recommendations from his uncle [[Oliver Messel]], and "society" portraits highly favoured in ''[[Tatler]]'', which, in addition to buying a lot of his photographs, gave him byline credit for the captions.{{cite book|last1=Cathcart|first1=Helen|title=Lord Snowdon|date=November 1968|publisher=W.H. Allen/Virgin Books|location=London|isbn=978-0491003810|edition=Hardback}} He later became known for his royal studies, among which were the official portraits of Queen [[Elizabeth II]] and the [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Duke of Edinburgh]] for their 1957 tour of Canada.{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11483331 | title = Obituary: Lord Snowdon |work=''BBC News''| accessdate = 13 January 2017|date= 13 January 2017}} He was also an early contributor to ''[[Queen (magazine)|Queen]]'' magazine, the magazine founded by his friend [[Jocelyn Stevens]].{{cite web|last1=Haden-Guest|first1=Anthony|title=The queen is dead|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/feb/12/pressandpublishing.observermagazine|website=The Guardian |access-date=24 November 2017 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221044241/https://www.theguardian.com/media/2006/feb/12/pressandpublishing.observermagazine |archive-date=21 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Sir Jocelyn Stevens (obituary)|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/11158471/Sir-Jocelyn-Stevens-obituary.html|website=The Telegraph (UK) |access-date=24 November 2017 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013201810/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/11158471/Sir-Jocelyn-Stevens-obituary.html |archive-date=13 October 2014|df=dmy-all}} In the early 1960s, Armstrong-Jones became the artistic adviser of ''[[The Sunday Times Magazine]]'', and by the 1970s had established himself as one of Britain's most respected photographers. Though his work included everything from fashion photography to documentary images of inner city life and the mentally ill, he is best known for his portraits of world notables, many of them published in ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', and ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' magazine. His subjects include [[Marlene Dietrich]]; [[Laurence Olivier]]; [[Maggie Smith]]; [[Leslie Caron]]; [[Lynn Fontanne]]; [[David Bowie]]; [[Elizabeth Taylor]]; [[Rupert Everett]]; [[Anthony Blunt]];{{cite web | url = http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portrait/mw19085/Anthony-Blunt | title = Anthony Blunt| publisher = National Portrait Gallery | accessdate = 13 January 2017}} [[David Hockney]]; [[Princess Grace of Monaco]]; [[Diana, Princess of Wales]]; [[Barbara Cartland]]; [[Raine Spencer, Countess Spencer|Raine Spencer (when she was Lady Lewisham)]]; [[Desmond Guinness]]; British prime minister [[Harold Macmillan]]; [[Iris Murdoch]]; [[Tom Stoppard]]; [[Vladimir Nabokov]]{{cite web|title=The Photography of Antony Armstrong-Jones|url=http://tatianacressidacoco.blogspot.com/2017/11/antonyajsnowdon.html|website=Royal Author Tatiana Coco|accessdate=26 November 2017}} and [[J. R. R. Tolkien]].{{cite web | url = http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/portrait/mw19287/JRR-Tolkien?set=256%3BPhotographs+by+Lord+Snowdon&search=ap&rNo=11 | publisher = National Portrait Gallery | title = J. R. R. Tolkien | accessdate = 13 January 2017}} Over 100 of his photographs are in the permanent collections of the [[National Portrait Gallery, London|National Portrait Gallery]] in London.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/13/world/europe/antony-armstrong-jones-earl-snowdon-dies.html|title=Antony Armstrong-Jones, Photographer and Earl of Snowdon, Dies at 86|work=The New York Times|first=Robert D.|last=McFadden|date=13 January 2017|accessdate=14 May 2018}} In 1968 he made his first documentary film, ''Don't Count the Candles'',{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b6caa1104|title=Don't Count the Candles (1968)|publisher=bfi.org.uk}} for the US television network [[CBS]], on the subject of ageing. It won seven awards{{cite web|title=Obituary: Lord Snowdon|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11483331|work=''BBC News'' |accessdate=17 January 2017}} including two [[Emmy]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/news-photo/lord-snowden-received-an-emmy-for-outstanding-cultural-dont-news-photo/534370710#lord-snowden-received-an-emmy-for-outstanding-cultural-dont-count-the-picture-id534370710|title=Lord Snowdon|publisher=gettyimages.co.uk}}{{cite news|title=1969 Press Photo Emmy Award Winners Lord Snowdon William McClure|url=https://outlet.historicimages.com/products/rsd76371|accessdate=17 January 2017|agency=United Press International|date=9 June 1969|format=News photo}} This was followed by ''Love of a kind'' (1969), about the British and animals,{{cite web|title=Love of a Kind|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b73c638a2|publisher=BFI|accessdate=17 January 2017}} ''Born to be small'' (1971) about people of restricted growth{{cite news|last1=Barnham|first1=Glen|title=Sadie Corré obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2009/sep/17/sadie-corre-obituary|accessdate=17 January 2017|work=The Guardian|date=17 September 2009}} and ''Happy being happy'' (1973).{{cite news|last1=Robertson|first1=Nan|title=A Life in Pictures: Lord Snowdon's 30 Years as a Photojournalist|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1979/11/10/archives/a-life-in-pictures-lord-snowdons-30-years-as-a-photojournalist-not.html|accessdate=17 January 2017|work=The New York Times|date=10 November 1979}} In October 1981 a group portrait by Snowdon of the British rock band [[Queen (band)|Queen]] was used on the cover of their ''[[Greatest Hits (Queen album)|Greatest Hits]]'' album. In 2000 A Snowdon portrait of [[Freddie Mercury]] was used on the cover of his ''[[The Solo Collection]]'' box set. In 2000, Armstrong-Jones was given a retrospective exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery, ''Photographs by Snowdon: A Retrospective'',{{cite web|url=http://www.npg.org.uk/whatson/exhibitions/2000/photographs-by-snowdon-a-retrospective.php|title=Photographs by Snowdon: A Retrospective|year=2000|work=Past exhibition archive|publisher=National Portrait Gallery|accessdate=13 January 2017}} which travelled to the [[Yale Center for British Art]] the following year.{{cite web|url=http://britishart.yale.edu/exhibitions/photographs-snowdon-retrospective-0|title=Photographs by Snowdon: A Retrospective|publisher=[[Yale University]]|accessdate=13 January 2017}} More than 180 of his photographs were displayed in an exhibition that honoured what the museums called "a rounded career with sharp edges". Snowdon was an Honorary Fellow of the [[Royal Photographic Society]] – he was awarded the Hood Medal of the Society in 1978 and the Progress Medal in 1985.{{cite web|url=http://rps.org/about/awards/history-and-recipients/hood-medal|title=Hood Medal – RPS|website=''rps.org''}}{{cite web|url=http://rps.org/about/awards/history-and-recipients/progress-medal|title=Progress Medal – RPS|website=''rps.org''}} In 2006, Tomas Maier, creative director of the Italian fashion brand [[Bottega Veneta]], sought Snowdon to photograph his Fall/Winter 2006 campaign.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cpp-luxury.com/bottega-venetas-fall-campaign-a-marketing-lesson-for-luxury-brands/|title=BOTTEGA VENETA's Fall campaign, a marketing lesson for luxury brands – CPP-LUXURY|date=3 August 2011|newspaper=CPP-LUXURY|access-date=18 January 2017}} == Designs and inventions == Armstrong-Jones co-designed (in 1963, with [[Frank Newby]] and [[Cedric Price]]) the "Snowdon Aviary" of the [[London Zoo]] (which opened in 1964); he later said it was one of his proudest creations, affectionately calling it the "birdcage".{{cite web|last1=Grice|first1=Elizabeth|title=Lord Snowdon: 'Taking photographs is a very nasty thing to do.'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/photography/7368664/Lord-Snowdon-Taking-photographs-is-a-very-nasty-thing-to-do.html|website=The Telegraph (UK) |access-date=25 November 2017 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100307050416/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/photography/7368664/Lord-Snowdon-Taking-photographs-is-a-very-nasty-thing-to-do.html |archive-date=7 March 2010|df=dmy-all}} He also had a major role in designing the physical arrangements for the [[Investiture of the Prince of Wales|1969 investiture of his nephew]] Prince Charles as [[Prince of Wales]].''Royal'', by [[Robert Lacey]], 2002. He was granted a patent for a type of [[electric wheelchair]] in 1971.{{cite patent| country = GB| number = 1230619| status = patent| title = Means for Providing Mobility for Physically Handicapped Persons| gdate = 5 May 1971| invent1 = A.C.R. Armstrong-Jones. Earl of Snowdon}} ==Philanthropy and charity== During his royal marriage, he was patron of the [[National Youth Theatre]], the [[Contemporary Art Society]] for Wales, the [[Theatre of Wales|Welsh Theatre]] Company, and the [[Civic Trust for Wales]]. He was also President of the British [[Theatre Museum]]. In June 1980 Lord Snowdon started an award scheme for disabled students. This scheme, administered by the Snowdon Trust, provides grants and scholarships for students with disabilities.{{cite web|title=The Snowdon Trust|url=https://www.snowdontrust.org/}} In the 1960s, he served in the capacity of a council member of the Polio Research Fund,{{cite book|last1=Cathcart|first1=Helen|title=Lord Snowdon|date=1968|publisher=W.H. Allen|location=London|page=70}} as it was known before it was renamed the National Fund for Research into Crippling Diseases. He served as a trustee of the National Fund for Research into Crippling Diseases (since renamed [[Action Medical Research]]). He was president for England of the [[International Year of Disabled Persons]] in 1981. He was provost of the [[Royal College of Art]] from 1995 to 2003.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jan/13/lord-snowdon-obituary|title=Lord Snowdon obituary|date=13 January 2017|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}} ==Personal life== Snowdon was married twice. He was married first to [[Princess Margaret, Countess of Snowdon|Princess Margaret]] (1960 to 1978), and second to Lucy Mary Lindsay-Hogg (1978 to 2000).{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/theroyalfamily/2059552/Lord-Snowdon-his-women-and-his-love-child.html|title=Lord Snowdon, his women, and his love child|date=31 May 2008|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|author=Alderson, Andrew}} ===First marriage=== [[File:Princess Margaret and Lord Snowdon with Lyndon B. Johnson and Lady Bird Johnson.jpg|thumb|Princess Margaret and the Earl of Snowdon with the United States president [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] and his wife [[Lady Bird Johnson|Lady Bird]] at the [[White House]] on 17 November 1965]] In February 1960, Snowdon, then known as Antony Armstrong-Jones, became engaged to the Queen's sister, Princess Margaret, and they married on 6 May 1960 at [[Westminster Abbey]]. The ceremony was the first royal wedding to be broadcast on television.{{Citation|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1384451/A-captivating-woman-who-was-courted-by-many-suitors-but-failed-to-find-lasting-love.html |title=A captivating woman...|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |author=Caroline Davies|date=10 February 2002 |accessdate=17 October 2008 }} Despite the public enthusiasm, "some critics disapproved of a commoner marrying into the royal family".{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/6/newsid_3993000/3993317.stm|title=1960: Margaret weds Armstrong-Jones|publisher=BBC|accessdate=14 May 2018}} The couple made their home in apartments at [[Kensington Palace]]. He was created '''Earl of Snowdon''' and '''Viscount Linley''', of [[Nymans]] in the [[County of Sussex]], on 6 October 1961.{{London Gazette |issue=42481 |date=6 October 1961 |page=7199}} The couple had two children: [[David Armstrong-Jones, 2nd Earl of Snowdon|David, 2nd Earl of Snowdon]], born 3 November 1961, and [[Lady Sarah Chatto|Lady Sarah]], born 1 May 1964. The marriage began to collapse early and publicly; various causes may have been behind the failure. On her side there was a penchant for late-night partying, while on Snowdon's an undisguised sexual profligacy. ("'If it moves, he'll have it,' was the summing-up of one close friend.")[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/non_fictionreviews/3554322/Lord-Snowdon-small-in-stature-big-in-bed.html "Snowdon: the Biography" by Anne de Courcy, reviewed by Duncan Fallowell], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 20 June 2008. "'[T]o most of the girls who worked in the Pimlico Road studio, there seemed little doubt that Tony was gay'. To which Tony responds: 'I didn't fall in love with boys - but a few men have been in love with me.'" The authorized biography by [[Anne de Courcy]] (2008) reveals a series of affairs with women, including a 20-year relationship with his mistress Ann Hills,{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2008/jun/22/biography.features|title=Talk about a cad and a bounder|work=The Guardian|first=Rachel|last=Cooke|date=21 June 2008|accessdate=14 May 2018}} and that Armstrong-Jones did not deny that he was bisexual. In his 2009 memoir, ''Redeeming Features'', British interior designer [[Nicholas Haslam]] claimed that he had an affair with Snowdon before the latter's marriage to Princess Margaret and that Snowdon had also been the lover of Tom Parr, another leading interior designer.{{cite news|url=https://www.wmagazine.com/story/nicky-haslam| work=W Magazine|title=Nicky Haslam|first1=James|last1=Reginato|date=1 December 2009}} The couple remained married sixteen years. "They were both pretty strong-willed and accustomed to having their own way, so there were bound to be collisions," according to de Courcy. His work also consumed a great deal of time. "She expected her husband to be with her more, but one of Tony's strongest motivations was work."{{cite web|url=http://www.townandcountrymag.com/society/news/a9255/princess-margaret-lord-snowdon-relationship/|title=The True Story of Princess Margaret and Antony Armstrong-Jones's Love Affair|publisher=Town & Country|first=Katie|last=Frost|date=8 December 2017|accessdate=14 May 2018}} The marriage was accompanied by drugs, alcohol and bizarre behaviour by both parties, such as his leaving lists of "things I hate about you" for the princess to find between the pages of books she read. According to biographers [[Sarah Bradford]], one note read: "You look like a Jewish manicurist and I hate you".{{cite book|last=Bradford|first=Sarah|title=Elizabeth|publisher=William Heinemann|location=London|year=1996}} When high society palled, Snowdon would escape to a hideaway cottage with his lovers or on overseas photographic assignments; "[m]ost people, including the Royal Family, took his side." Among Snowdon's lovers in the late 1960s was Lady Jacqueline Rufus-Isaacs, daughter of the [[Michael Alfred Rufus Isaacs, 3rd Marquess of Reading|3rd Marquess of Reading]]. In spite of her own affairs, Margaret was said to be particularly upset when hearing about this woman. They separated in 1976, and the marriage ended in divorce in 1978.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/march/19/newsid_4243000/4243211.stm|title=1976: Princess Margaret and Lord Snowdon to split|work=''BBC News''|accessdate=13 January 2016}} In 2004, ''The Telegraph'' reported that Snowdon had fathered an illegitimate daughter shortly before marrying Princess Margaret.Andy Bloxham, Andy (31 May 2008). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/theroyalfamily/2056112/Lord-Snowdon-fathered-a-secret-love-child-just-months-before-marrying-Princess-Margaret.html "Lord Snowdon fathered a secret love child just months before marrying Princess Margaret"]. ''[[The Sunday Telegraph]]''. Retrieved 28 June 2008. Anne de Courcy reports the claim by Polly Fry, born on 28 May 1960, in the third week of Lord Snowdon's marriage to Princess Margaret, and brought up as a daughter of [[Jeremy Fry]], inventor and member of the [[J. S. Fry & Sons|Fry's]] chocolate family, and his first wife, Camilla, that she was in fact Snowdon's daughter.Conti, Samantha (21 November 2008). "The Tony Earl". ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]''. p. 10. Polly Fry asserted that a [[DNA test]] in 2004 proved Snowdon's paternity. Jeremy Fry rejected her claim, and Snowdon denied having taken a DNA test. However, four years later, he admitted that this account was true. ===Second marriage=== After his divorce from Princess Margaret, Lord Snowdon married Lucy Mary Lindsay-Hogg (née Davies) on 15 December 1978. Armstrong-Jones's youngest daughter is Lady Frances Armstrong-Jones, a designer and board member of the Snowdon Trust.{{cite web|title=Our board|url=https://www.snowdontrust.org/our-board|website=The Snowdon Trust}} She was born on 17 July 1979 and married Rodolphe von Hofmannsthal in 2006.{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/snowdons-daughter-marries-f0j5p5c8nw3|title=Snowdon's daughter marries|publisher=The Times|date=3 December 2006|accessdate=4 October 2018}} From 1976 until 1996, Snowdon also had a mistress, journalist Ann Hills. She died by suicide on 31 December 1996. The couple separated in 2000 after the revelation that Snowdon, then aged 67, had fathered a son, Jasper William Oliver Cable-Alexander (born 30 April 1998), with Melanie Cable-Alexander, an editor at ''[[Country Life (magazine)|Country Life]]'' magazine.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/3592805/Still-playing-Peter-Pan.html|title=Still playing Peter Pan|date=16 April 2003|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|author=Bearn, Emily}}Owens, Mitchell (27 July 1999). [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/06/27/style/noticed-blood-tells-so-does-burke-s.html "Noticed: Blood Tells. So Does Burke's"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved 5 September 2017. ===Death=== Lord Snowdon died peacefully at his home in [[Kensington]] on 13 January 2017, aged 86.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-38611497|title=Lord Snowdon dies aged 86|work=''BBC News''|date=13 January 2017|accessdate=13 January 2017}} His funeral took place on 20 January at [[St Baglan's Church, Llanfaglan|St Baglan's Church]] in the remote village of [[Llanfaglan]] near [[Caernarfon]]. He was buried in the family plot in the churchyard.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailypost.co.uk/news/north-wales-news/lord-snowdon-funeral-royal-caernarfon-12483485|title=Lord Snowdon laid to rest at family service near Caernarfon|first=Eryl|last=Crump|date=20 January 2017|publisher=dailypost.co.uk|accessdate=20 January 2017}} ==Titles, styles, honours and arms== ===Titles=== *'''7 March 1930 – 6 October 1961''': ''Mr'' Antony Armstrong-Jones *'''6 October 1961 – 13 January 2017''': ''The Right Honourable'' The Earl of Snowdon **'''16 November 1999 – 13 January 2017''': ''The Right Honourable'' The Lord Armstrong-Jones === Peerage === Following his wedding, Armstrong-Jones was granted an earldom"No. 42481". The London Gazette. 6 October 1961. p. 7199. and introduced to the House of Lords as the Earl of Snowdon on 28 February 1962.{{cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/lords/1962/feb/28/the-earl-of-snowdon#S5LV0237P0_19620228_HOL_3|title=THE EARL OF SNOWDON (Hansard, 28 February 1962)|website=hansard.millbanksystems.com}} The awarding of the earldom was in line with the practice of granting titles upon marriage into the Royal Family."The Peerage". Whitaker's Concise Almanack. 2003. pp. 134–169. {{ISBN|0-7136-6498-3}}. Snowdon was appointed [[Castellan|Constable]] of [[Caernarfon Castle]] in 1963; as part of this role, he assisted in organising the [[Investiture of the Prince of Wales#Investiture of Prince Charles|Investiture of the Prince of Wales]] in 1969.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dailypost.co.uk/news/north-wales-news/tributes-gentleman-lord-snowdon-who-12452935|title=Tributes to 'gentleman' Lord Snowdon|last=Bagnall|first=Steve|date=13 January 2018|work=northwales|access-date=29 April 2018}} He made his maiden speech in the House of Lords in April 1972{{cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/lords/1974/apr/10/mobility-of-the-physically-disabled#S5LV0350P0_19740410_HOL_138|title=Mobility of the Physically Disabled (Hansard, 10 April 1974)|website=hansard.millbanksystems.com}} on the problems that disabled people suffered in everyday life.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/register/earl-of-snowdon-0fd88tnwx|title=Obituary: Earl of Snowdon|work=The Times}} One of his last contributions to the Lords was in response to the [[Queen's Speech]] of 1992.{{cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/lords/1992/may/12/address-in-reply-to-her-majestys-most#S5LV0537P0_19920512_HOL_107|title=Address in Reply to Her Majesty's Most Gracious Speech|publisher=UK Parliament|date=12 May 1992|accessdate=14 May 2018}} On 16 November 1999 Lord Snowdon was created '''Baron Armstrong-Jones''', of Nymans in the County of West Sussex.{{London Gazette |issue=55672 |date=19 November 1999 |page=12349}} This was a [[life peer]]age given to him so that he could keep his seat in the [[House of Lords]] after the hereditary peers had been [[House of Lords Act 1999|excluded]]. An offer of a life peerage was made to all hereditary peers of the first creation (those for whom a peerage was originally created, as opposed to those who inherited a peerage from an ancestor) at that time. The government of the day had expected Lord Snowdon to follow the example of members of the royal family and turn down his right to a life peerage. At the time, Labour MP [[Fraser Kemp]] said he was "shocked and surprised that someone who achieved their position in the House of Lords by virtue of marriage should accept a seat in the reformed Lords".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/1999/nov/03/lordreform.constitution|date=3 November 1999|accessdate=16 January 2015|last=Watt|title=Dismay as Snowdon stays in Lords|first=Nicholas|work=The Guardian}} Snowdon retired from the House of Lords on 31 March 2016{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/biographies/lords/earl-of-snowdon/3150|title=Earl of Snowdon}} having seldom attended{{cite web|url=http://www.publicwhip.org.uk/mp.php?id=uk.org.publicwhip/member/100604&showall=yes#divisions|title=Voting Record – The Earl of Snowdon (13657) – The Public Whip|website=''publicwhip.org.uk''}} nor claimed any expenses for many years.{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/documents/lords-finance-office/holallowances0102.pdf|title=House of Lords – Members' Expenses 1 April 2001 – 31 March 2002|publisher=UK Parliament}}{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/documents/lords-finance-office/2015-16/allowances-expenses-2015-16-month-12-march.pdf|title=House of Lords Publication of Financial Support for Members 1 – 31 March 2016|publisher=UK Parliament}} === Awards and honours === * GCVO: [[Royal Victorian Order|Knight Grand Cross of the Royal Victorian Order]], 7 July 1969{{London Gazette |issue=44888 |date=3 July 1969 |page=6967 |supp=y}} * He was awarded the [[Royal Photographic Society]]'s [[Progress Medal (RPS)|Progress Medal]] and an Honorary Fellowship in 1985.{{cite web|url=http://rps.org/about/awards/history-and-recipients/progress-medal|title=Progress Medal|publisher=The Royal Photographic Society|accessdate=16 July 2013}} * In 1989, he was awarded an Honorary [[Doctor of Laws]] (LL.D.) from the [[University of Bath]].{{cite web |url= http://www.bath.ac.uk/ceremonies/hongrads/|title=Honorary Graduates 1989 to present|publisher=[[University of
