'''Marcel Pauker''' (rendered in [[Russian language|Russian]] as ''Марцел Паукер'' - ''Martsel Pauker''; December 6, 1896, [[Bucharest]] – August 16, 1938, [[Yuzhnoye Butovo District|Butovo]], near [[Moscow]]) was a [[Romania]]n [[communist]] [[Militant (word)|militant]] and husband of the future Romanian Communist leader [[Ana Pauker]].
During his life, Pauker took a series of [[pseudonym]]s, the ones used most being: ''Burghezul'', ''Herman Gugenheim'', ''Paul Lampart'', ''Luximin'', ''Puiu'', ''Priu'', ''Semionovici Marin'', ''Stepan'', and ''Paul Weiss''.
==Early life==
Born to a [[Secular Jewish culture|secular Jewish]] family, Marcel Pauker was a [[Multilingual|polyglot]], and noted speaker of [[Esperanto]]. He briefly studied [[engineering]] in [[Zürich]], before enlisting as an [[artillery]] [[cadet]] and becoming a Second Lieutenant in 1916 (during [[World War I]]). Between 1919 and 1921, he lived in [[Switzerland]] for a second time, receiving his [[diploma]] in engineering.
==Militancy==
In December 1921, Pauker was designated a member of the Provisional Committee of the [[Romanian Communist Party]]; in 1922, his position became that of member of the Central Committee and the [[Politburo]], being sent as [[delegate]] to the [[Balkan Communist Federation]] Conferences in [[Sofia]] (June 1922) and [[Berlin]] (1923). His activities brought him to the attention of the Romanian authorities: he was arrested and sentenced first to ten years imprisonment, and then to [[Penal labour|labour]] for life. Nevertheless, he managed to escape and flee to the [[Soviet Union]] in 1925, returning to Romania in 1929. On his arrival he was escorted back to prison, only to be released under the terms of an [[amnesty]]. He was yet again arrested in [[Petroşani]], after his activities as an instigator during the [[Jiu Valley]] [[Lupeni Strike of 1929|miners' strike of August 1929]].
==Final years and death==
Marcel Pauker got involved in a political fight with [[Vitali Holostenco]], reflecting the struggle between the Bucharest section and that of the [[Ukrainian SSR]] that had taken hold of the Party's wing inside the Soviet Union around the proceedings of the 4th Congress in [[Kharkiv]]. Again in the Soviet Union, Pauker was reprimanded by the [[Comintern]]. Forbidden from contributing to political activities, he was sent to assist as an engineer in the industrial expansion of [[Magnitogorsk]] (in western [[Siberia]]), a job he undertook between 1930 and 1932. At the same time, [[Joseph Stalin]], whose priority at the time was showing the facade of "unity" within his subject Parties, had Holostenco removed from his position.
In 1935 Pauker was appointed a member of the [[wikt:secretariat|Secretariat]] of the Romanian Communist Party. He spent time in [[Prague]] until 1937, when he returned to the Soviet Union. He fell victim to the [[Great Purge]]: arrested by the [[NKVD]] on March 21, 1937 and held in the infamous [[Taganka Prison]], Marcel Pauker was first interrogated over a year later, being presented with the charge of [[espionage]] in favor of Romania. Records show that he finally admitted to the charge (most likely after being subjected to [[torture]]). Consequently, he was put on trial, sentenced to death and [[Execution (legal)|executed]] by [[Execution by firing squad|shooting]].<ref>Tudoran</ref>
==Rehabilitation==
Marcel Pauker was [[Rehabilitation (Soviet)|rehabilitated]] by Soviet authorities in 1957 (as part of the [[History of the Soviet Union (1953-1985)|De-Stalinization]] process under [[Nikita Khrushchev]]). [[Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej]]'s rejection of newer Soviet policies prevented this and other such cases from being mirrored in [[Communist Romania]]. While Gheorghiu-Dej was exercising a looser control of the society, he was not ready to question most of the [[Stalinism|Stalinist]] measures, as these had served to enforce his own rule during the previous decade.
The case was reconsidered under [[Nicolae Ceauşescu]]'s further distancing measures. Pauker's name was cleared, but mention of his activities and details of his life were kept secret.
==Family==
Largely thanks to circumstances, Ana Pauker was able to survive her husband's downfall, and she even reached the peak of her political career in the following years.
They had three children together: *'''Tanio''' (1921-1922) *'''Vlad''' (1926-2016) *'''Tatiana''' (1928-2011)
Vlad moved to France.
In 1931 Marcel also fathered a son named '''Yakov''', from his relationship with fellow militant '''Roza Elbert'''.
He also had lengthy affairs with [[Elena Filipovici]] and [[Vanda Nicolschi]].

English intertitles | budget = | gross = }} '''''Martyrs of the Alamo''''' (also known as '''''The Birth of Texas''''') is a 1915 American [[Historical film|historical]] [[War film|war drama film]] written and directed by [[Christy Cabanne]]. The film is based on the historical novel of the same name by Theodosia Harris, and features an ensemble cast including [[Sam De Grasse]], [[Douglas Fairbanks]], [[Walter Long (actor)|Walter Long]] and [[Alfred Paget]].{{cite web|url=http://www.silentera.com/PSFL/data/M/MartyrsOfTheAlamo1915.html|title=The Martyrs of the Alamo; or, "The Birth of Texas"|publisher=silentera.com|accessdate=May 29, 2013}} Fairbanks role was uncredited, and was his first role in film, although his first starring role, in ''[[The Lamb]]'', was released prior to this picture.{{cite web| url=https://catalog.afi.com/Catalog/MovieDetails/16586 | publisher=American Film Institute | title=The Martyrs of the Alamo | accessdate=August 9, 2018}} The film features the [[Siege of Béxar]], [[Battle of the Alamo]] and [[Battle of San Jacinto]]. While making claims to historical accuracy, the film depicts the Mexican population in [[San Antonio]] in 1836 as a group of ill-mannered drunks. One scene depicts a Mexican officer verbally assaulting a white woman and making advances on her. The white woman reports the incident to her husband, [[Almeron Dickinson]] who in turn shoots the Mexican officer. In his book ''Remembering the Alamo'', author Richard R. Flores, argues that the negative portrayal of the Mexican population is due to racism toward Mexicans in 1915, the year the film was produced.{{cite book|last=Flores|first=Richard R. |title=Remembering the Alamo: Memory, Modernity, and Thew Master Symbol|year=2002|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=0-292-78196-2|pages=99–100}} A copy of the film is preserved at the [[Library of Congress]]. == Cast == *[[Sam De Grasse]] as Silent Smith ([[Deaf Smith]]) *[[Allan Sears]] as [[David Crockett]] *[[Walter Long (actor)|Walter Long]] as [[Santa Anna (Comanche war chief)|Santa Anna]] *[[Alfred Paget]] as [[James Bowie]] *[[Fred Burns (actor)|Fred Burns]] as [[Almeron Dickinson]] *[[John T. Dillon (actor)|John T. Dillon]] as [[William B. The title '''mnemonist''' (derived from the term [[mnemonic]]) refers to an individual with the ability to remember and recall unusually long lists of data, such as unfamiliar names, lists of numbers, entries in books, etc. The duration of superior retention can be minutes, hours, days, or decades. Mnemonists may have superior innate ability to recall or remember,{{citation needed|date=August 2014}} or may use techniques such as the [[method of loci]].
==Structure of mnemonic skills== While the innateness of mnemonists' skills is debated, the methods that mnemonists use to memorize are well-documented. Many mnemonists have been studied in [[psychology]] labs over the last century, and most have been found to use mnemonic devices. Currently, all memory champions at the [[World Memory Championships]] have said that they use mnemonic strategies, such as the [[method of loci]], to perform their memory feats.
Skilled memory theory was proposed by [[K. Anders Ericsson]] and Bill Chase to explain the effectiveness of mnemonic devices in memory expertise. Generally, [[short-term memory]] has a capacity of [[The Magical Number Seven, Plus or Minus Two|seven items]];<ref>{{cite journal|author=Miller, G. A.|year=1956|title=The magical number seven, plus or minus two: Some limits on our capacity for processing information|journal=Psychological Review|volume=63|issue=2|pages=343–355|url=http://psychclassics.yorku.ca/Miller/| doi=10.1037/h0043158|pmid=13310704}}</ref> however, in order to memorize long strings of unrelated information, this constraint must be overcome. Skilled memory theory involves three steps: meaningful encoding, retrieval structure, and speed-up.<ref name=Ericsson>{{cite journal|authors=Chase, W. G., and Ericsson, K. A.|year=1982|title=Skill and working memory|editor=G. H. Bower|journal=Psychology of Learning and Motivation|volume=16|pages=1–58|doi=10.1016/S0079-7421(08)60546-0}}</ref>
===Encoding=== In encoding, information is encoded in terms of knowledge structures through meaningful associations. This may initially involve breaking down long lists into more manageable [[chunking (psychology)|chunks]] that fall within the capacity of short term memory. Verbal reports of memory experts show a consistent grouping of three or four. A digit sequence 1-9-4-5, for example, can then be remembered as "the year World War Two ended". Luria reported that [[Solomon Shereshevsky]] used [[synesthesia]] to associate numbers and words as visual images or colors to encode the information presented to him, but Luria did not clearly distinguish between synesthesia and mnemonic techniques like the method of loci and number shapes.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://mt.artofmemory.com/wiki/Number_Shape_System | title=Number Shape System | work=Memory Techniques Wiki | accessdate=May 19, 2016}}</ref><ref name=Luria>{{cite book|author=Luria, A.|year=1987|title=The Mind of a Mnemonist|location=Cambridge|publisher=Harvard University Press}}</ref> Other subjects studied have used previous knowledge such as racing times or historical information<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Ericsson, K., Delaney, P., & Weaver, G.|year=2004|title=Uncovering the structure of a memorist's superior "basic" memory capacity|journal=Cognitive Psychology|volume=49|issue=3|pages=191–237|url=http://www.chrest.info/Fribourg_Cours_Expertise/Articles-www/II%20Donnees%20empiriques/ericsson-mnemonics.pdf|doi=10.1016/j.cogpsych.2004.02.001}}</ref> to encode new information. This is supported by studies that have shown that previous knowledge about a subject will increase one's ability to remember it. Chess experts, for example, can memorize more pieces of a chess game in progress than a novice chess player.<ref name=Ericsson/> However, while there is some correlation between memory expertise and general [[intelligence]], as measured by either [[IQ]] or the [[general intelligence factor]], the two are by no means identical. Many memory experts have been shown to be average to above-average by these two measures, but not exceptional.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Conway, A.R.A.|title=Working Memory Capacity and its relation to general intelligence|year=2003|journal=Trends in Cognitive Sciences|volume=7|issue=12|pages=547–552|pmid=14643371|doi=10.1016/j.tics.2003.10.005}}</ref>
===Retrieval=== The next step is to create a retrieval structure by which the associations can be recalled. It serves the function of storing retrieval cues without having to use short term memory. It is used to preserve the order of items to be remembered. Verbal reports of memory experts show two prominent methods of retrieving information: hierarchical nodes and the method of loci. Retrieval structures are hierarchically organized and can be thought of as nodes that are activated when information is retrieved. Verbal reports have shown that memory experts have different retrieval structures. One expert clustered digits into groups, groups into supergroups, and supergroups into clusters of supergroups. However, by far the most common method of retrieval structure is the method of loci.<ref name=Eric>{{cite journal | author = Ericsson K | year = 2003 | title = Exceptional Memorizers: made, not born | url = | journal = Trends in Cognitive Sciences | volume = 7 | issue = 6| pages = 233–235 | doi=10.1016/s1364-6613(03)00103-7 | pmid=12804685}}</ref>
===Method of loci=== {{Main|Method of loci}} The method of loci is "the use of an orderly arrangement of locations into which one could place the images of things or people that are to be remembered".<ref>{{cite journal|author=Bower, G.|year=1970|title=Analysis of a Mnemonic Device|journal=American Scientist|volume=58|pages=496–510|url=http://stanford.edu/~gbower/1970/Analysis_of_a_mnemonic_device.pdf}}</ref> The encoding process happens in three steps. First, an architectural area, such as the houses on a street, must be memorized. Second, each item to be remembered must be associated with a separate image. Finally, this set of images can be distributed in a "locus," or place within the architectural area in a pre-determined order. Then, as one tries to recall the information, the mnemonists simply has to "walk" down the street, see each symbol, and recall the associated information. An example of mnemonists who used this is [[Solomon Shereshevsky]]; he would use [[Gorky Street]], a street he lived on. When he read, each word would form a graphic image. He would then place this image in a place along the street; later, when he needed to recall the information, he would simply "stroll" down the street again to recall the necessary information.<ref name=Luria/> [[Neuroimaging]] studies have shown results that support the method of loci as the retrieval method in world-class memory performers. An [[fMRI]] recorded brain activity in memory experts and a control group as they were memorizing selected data. Previous studies have shown that teaching a control group the method of loci leads to changes in brain activation during memorization. Consistent with their use of the method of loci, memory experts had higher activity in the medial [[parietal cortex]], retrospenial cortex, and right posterior [[hippocampus]]; these brain areas have been linked to [[spatial memory|spatial memory and navigation]]. These differences were observable even when the memory experts were trying to memorize stimuli, such as snowflakes, where they showed no superior ability to the control group.<ref name=Maguire>{{cite journal|author=Maguire, E.|year=2003|title=Routes to remembering: the brains behind superior memory|journal=Nature Neuroscience|volume=6|issue=1|pages=90–95|pmid=12483214|doi=10.1038/nn988}}</ref>
===Acceleration=== The final step in skilled memory theory is acceleration. With practice, time necessary for encoding and retrieval operations can be dramatically reduced. As a result, storage of information can then be performed within a few seconds. Indeed, one confounding factor in the study of memory is that the subjects often improve from day-to-day as they are tested over and over.
== Learned skill or innate ability == The innateness of expert performance in the memory field has been studied thoroughly by many scientists; it is a matter which has still not been definitively resolved.
===Evidence for memory expertise as a learned skill=== Much evidence exists which points towards memory expertise as a learned skill which can only be learned through hours of deliberate practice. Anecdotally, the performers in top memory competitions like the [[World Memory Championships]] and the [[Extreme Memory Tournament]] all deny any ability of a photographic memory; rather, these experts have averaged 10 years practicing their encoding strategies.<ref name=Eric/> Another piece of evidence which points away from an innate superiority of memory is the specificity of memory expertise in memorists. For example, though memory experts have an exceptional ability to remember digits, their ability to remember unrelated items which are more difficult to encode, such as symbols or snowflakes, is the same as that of an average person. The same holds true for memory experts in other fields: studies of [[mental calculator]]s and chess experts show the same specificity for superior memory.<ref name=Ericsson/><ref name=Eric/><ref name=Maguire/> In some cases, other types of memory, such as [[visual memory]] for faces, may even be impaired.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Raz A|title=A slice of pi: an exploratory neuroimaging study of digit encoding and retrieval in a superior memorist|journal=Neurocase|year=2009|volume=15|issue=5|pages=361–72|doi=10.1080/13554790902776896|pmc=4323087|pmid=19585350}}</ref> Another piece of evidence of memory expertise as a learned ability is the fact that dedicated individuals can make exceptional memory gains when exposed to mnemonics and given a chance to practice. One subject, SF, a college student of average intelligence, was able to attain world-class memory performance after hundreds of hours of practice over two years. His memory, in fact, improved over 70 standard deviations, while his digit span, or [[memory span]] for digits, grew to 80 digits, which was higher than the digit span for all memory experts previously recorded.<ref name=Ericsson/> Similarly, adults of average intelligence taught encoding strategies also show large gains in memory performance. Finally, neuroimaging studies performed on memory experts and compared to a control group have found no systematic anatomical differences in the brain between memory experts and a control group.<ref name=Maguire/> While it is true that there are activation differences between the brains of memory experts and a control group, these are due to the use of spatial techniques to form retrieval structures, not any structural differences.
===Evidence for memory expertise as an innate ability=== Much of the evidence for innate superiority of memory is anecdotal and is therefore rejected by scientists who have moved toward accepting only reproducible studies as evidence for elite performance. There have been exceptions, however, that do not fit skilled memory theory as proposed by Chase and Ericsson. Synesthetes, for example, show a memory advantage for material that induces their synesthesia over a control group. This advantage tends to be in retention of new information rather than learning. However, synesthetes are likely to have some brain differences which give them an innate advantage when it comes to memory.<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Yaro, C., & Ward, J.|year=2007|title=Searching for Shereshevskii: What is superior about the memory of synaesthetes?|journal=Quarterly [[Journal of Experimental Psychology]]|volume=60|issue=5|pages=681–695|pmid=17455076|doi=10.1080/17470210600785208}}</ref> Another group which may have some innate memory advantage are [[savant syndrome|autistic savants]]. Unfortunately, many savants who have performed memory feats, such as [[Kim Peek]] and [[Daniel Tammet]], have not been studied in a lab; they do claim to not need to use encoding strategies. A recent imaging study of savants found that there are activation differences between savants and typically developing individuals; these cannot be explained by the method of loci as mnemonic savants do not tend to use encoding strategies for their memory. Savants activated the right inferior [[occipital lobe|occipital areas]] of their brain, whereas control participants activated the left parietal region which is generally associated with attentional processes.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Neumann, N|year=2010|title=The Mind of the Mnemonists: An MEG and Neuropsychological Study of Autistic Memory Savants|journal=[[Behavioural Brain Research]]|volume=215|issue=1|pages=114–121|doi=10.1016/j.bbr.2010.07.008|pmid=20637245}}</ref>
==Famous mnemonists== * [[Yanjaa|Yanjaa Wintersoul]]: double world record holding memory champion.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iam-stats.com/athlete.php?id=13559|title=Official Statistics|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> * [[Derren Brown]] * [[Creighton Carvello]] * [[Dominic O'Brien]]: 8x [[World Memory Championships|world memory champion]] (1991, 1993, 1995–97, 1999–01).<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=http://www.world-memory-statistics.com/c_world.php|title=World Memory Championships {{!}} World Memory Statistics|website=www.world-memory-statistics.com|access-date=2016-12-29}}</ref> * [[Ben Pridmore]]: 3x world memory champion (2004, 2008–09).<ref name="auto"/> * [[Harry Lorayne]] * [[Edward Cyril De Hault Laston]] * [[Rajan Mahadevan]] * [http://www.pi-world-ranking-list.com/lists/nation/ind.html List of all people from India who have memorized large numbers of digits of pi] * [[Kim Peek]], the real-life inspiration for the character of Raymond in the film ''[[Rain Man]]'' * [[Shass Pollak]] * [[S.V. Shereshevskii]], from AR Luria's ''The Mind of a Mnemonist'' * [[Daniel Tammet]] * [[Ed Cooke (author)|Ed Cooke]]: author and [[Grand Master of Memory|grandmaster of memory]] * [[Wang Feng (mnemonist)|Wang Feng]]: 2x world memory champion (2010–11).<ref name="auto"/> * [[Johannes Mallow]]: world memory champion (2012).<ref name="auto"/> * [[Jonas von Essen]]: 2x world memory champion (2013–14).<ref name="auto"/> * [[Alex Mullen (memory athlete)|Alex Mullen]]: 3x world memory champion (2015–17).<ref name="auto"/> * [[Nelson Dellis]]: 4x [[USA Memory Championship|USA memory champion]] (2011–12, 2014–15).<ref name="artofmemory.com">{{cite web|url=http://mt.artofmemory.com/wiki/List_of_USA_Memory_Champions|title=List of USA Memory Champions - Memory Techniques Wiki|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Ron White (memory expert)|Ron White]]: 2x USA memory champion (2009–10).<ref name="artofmemory.com"/> * [[Joshua Foer]]: author and USA memory champion (2006).<ref name="artofmemory.com"/> * [[Brad Williams (mnemonist)|Brad Williams]] * [[Dave Farrow]]: most playing cards memorized after a single sighting, with 59 decks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/most-decks-of-playing-cards-memorized-single-sighting|title=Most decks of playing cards memorized - single sighting {{!}} Guinness World Records|website=www.guinnessworldrecords.com|access-date=2016-12-29}}</ref> * [https://www.google.co.in/search?hl=en&tbm=bks&tbm=bks&q=inauthor:%22N.+L.+Shraman%22&sa=X&ei=qt6CUO_0MIrZrQe5lYHwCA&ved=0CDEQ9AgwAA Shraman N L], [[Republic of India]] * [[Arun Phoke]], [[Aurangabad, Maharashtra|Aurangabad]], [[Maharashtra]] * [[Femi Francis Akinsiku (mnemonist)|Femi Francis Akinsiku]] * [[Nidhip Vora]], [[Upleta]], [[Gujarat]], memory expert, researcher of IRSRO mnemonic system of memory, [[psychologist]]
[[Memory sport]] contains a more comprehensive list of well-known memory athletes. The complete, up-to-date memory world rankings can be found at the [[International Association of Memory]] website.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iam-stats.com/rankings.php|title=World Ranking {{!}} International Association of Memory Statistics|website=www.iam-stats.com|access-date=2016-12-30}}</ref>

Amrita Ma (his grandmother and his religious teacher) | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = {{URL|http://www.moraribapu.org/}} | footnotes = }} {{Vaishnavism}} '''Morari Bapu''' ({{lang-gu|મોરારી બાપુ}}, {{lang-hi|मुरारी बापू}}; real name '''Moraridas Prabhudas Hariyani''') was born on 25 September 1946[http://www.yogausa.com/saints_morari_bapu.php Moraridas (Bapu) showed signs of extraordinary brilliance and spent most of his childhood under the guidance of his grandmother often spending hours listening to folk tales of traditional India. Bapu was born on 25 September 1946 in Talgajarda (a small village near the port of Mahuva in the State of Gujarat, India), to Prabhudas Bapu Hariyani and Savitri Ben Hariyani.] in Talgajarda near [[Mahuva (Bhavnagar district)|Mahuva]], [[Gujarat]]. He is a popular [[Hindu]] ''kathakaar'' (bard), who has been giving 9 day-long Spiritual and religious talks/ programs (''[[Katha (storytelling format)|kathaa]]''s) in both [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] and [[Hindi]] all over the world—including in [[India]], the [[United States]], the [[United Kingdom]], [[South Africa]], [[Kenya]], [[Uganda]], on a cruise ship in the [[Mediterranean Sea]], and on an airplane travelling the world, in the Vatican City and in the foothills of Mount Kailas in Tibet/China—since his first katha in 1960. To date, he has conducted over 800 ''kathaa''s, most of them based on the ''[[Ramcharitmanas]]'' of [[Tulsidas]] and other such works about [[Rama]] as well as Gopigeet which has the gopis of Vrindavan singing of the glory of [[Krishna]] in Krishna's separation. ==Biography== Morari Bapu, complete name Moraridas Prabhudas Hariyani was born on 2 March 1946 on auspicious day of ashvin krishan amavasaya and also Shivratri in village [[Talgajarda]] near [[Mahuva (Bhavnagar district)|Mahuva]], [[Gujarat]], to Prabhudas Bapu Hariyani and Savitri Ben Hariyani, in a family of six brothers and two sisters. He is born in a family following religious traditions called Vaishnav Bava Sadhu [[Nimbarka Sampradaya]] (lineage). He became to be lovingly referred to as "Bapu" (meaning Father or elderly person) by people.[http://www.yogausa.com/saints_morari_bapu.php Morari Bapu Profile] www.yogausa.com.[http://www.moraribapu.org/moraribapu_biography.html Biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131221140038/http://moraribapu.org/moraribapu_biography.html |date=21 December 2013 }} www.moraribapu.org His grandfather, Tribhovandasji was a great [[Rama]] Bhakta (devotee of Shri [[Rama]]) and used to make young Morari memorize five verses of the ''Ramcharitamanas'' each day, on his way to school and back. Further, At a young age he was also encouraged via letters from his grandfather younger brother, Mahamandleshwar Vishnu Giriji Maharaj, who was head of "Kailas Ashram" at [[Rishikesh]], to be proficient in the ''[[Bhagavad Gita]]'' and the [[Vedas]].[http://www.dalsabzi.com/books/in_touch_with_masters/sri_morari_bapu.htm Sri Morari Bapu][http://profiles.incredible-people.com/sant-morari-bapu/ Sant Morari Bapu] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120718090312/http://profiles.incredible-people.com/sant-morari-bapu/ |date=18 July 2012 }} profiles.incredible-people.com. Morari Bapu started his career as a primary school teacher in a nearby village to Talgajarda. He worked there for several years, while also doing Ram Kathas. ==Quotes== {{BLP unsourced section |date= October 2018}} * रोज इन पांचो का दर्शन कुछ समय के लिए करो - देव दर्शन, प्रकृति दर्शन, संत दर्शन, शास्त्र दर्शन, निज ह्रदय दर्शन. (Every day spend a few moments giving thought and time to God, to nature, your sadguru/ saint, your scripture, and finally your own self.) * एकवीसमी सदी का त्याग करुणा से निकालना चाहिए. (Sacrifices of the twenty-first century should be with compassion.) * भक्त सदा ज्ञानी ही होता है, भक्त कभी मूढ़ नहीं होता. (A devotee is always wise, he is never deluded.) * सुख पूर्ण दुःख झेलना तप है. (Happily enduring all the hardships in life is Tap {Tapasaya}.) *‌ "સત્ય પ્રેમ કરુણા" (Truth , love , compassion) ==References== {{Commons category}} {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.moraribapu.org Official website of Morari Bapu (www.moraribapu.org)] *[http://www.jerusalemtour.co.il/?p=1583&lang=en Morari Bapu in Jerusalem] *[http://www.wahh.in/2017/05/Morari-Bapu-30-Quotes-In-Hindi.html Morari Bapu 30 Quotes Thought In Hindi] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bapu, Morari}} [[Category:Bhakti movement]] [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Gujarati people]] [[Category:Indian Hindu spiritual teachers]] [[Category:Indian storytellers]]

Prins |image =Nomi Prins in June 2017 at a Congressional briefing.jpg |image_size = |caption = Prins in June 2017 at a Congressional briefing |birth_place = Poughkeepsie, NY |other_names = |known_for = ''All the Presidents' Bankers: The Hidden Alliances that Drive American Power''

''Other People's Money'' |occupation = Author, Journalist and Senior Fellow at Demos |nationality = [[United States]] |alma_mater = [[New York University]] |awards = |education = [[Leonard N. Stern School of Business]] |website = [http://www.nomiprins.com/ nomiprins.com] }} '''Nomi Prins''' is an American [[author]], [[journalist]], and public speaker who writes about Wall Street and the American economy. Prins worked as a managing director at [[Goldman Sachs]] for 2 years and as a Senior Managing Director at [[Bear Stearns]] for 7 years, and was a senior strategist at [[Lehman Brothers]] and an analyst at the [[Chase Manhattan Bank]]. Prins is known for her book ''All the Presidents' Bankers'' in which she explores over a century of close relationships between the 19 Presidents from [[Teddy Roosevelt]] through [[Barack Obama]] and the key bankers of their day based on original archival documents. Prins also received recognition for her [[whistleblower]] book, ''It Takes a Pillage: Behind the Bonuses, Bailouts, and Backroom Deals from Washington to Wall Street'', for her views on the [[U.S. economy]],{{cite web|url=http://www.c-span.org/video/?290057-1/words-nomi-prins |title=''After Words'' with Nomi Prins|publisher=[[Book TV]] |date= |accessdate=2015-04-22}}{{cite web|last=Leopold |first=Les |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/les-leopold/to-create-jobs-on-main-st_b_348183.html |title=To Create Jobs on Main Street, We Need to Kill Jobs on Wall Street |publisher=Huffington Post |date=November 6, 2009 |accessdate=2012-06-18}}http://www.counterpunch.org/2014/12/16/how-change-is-stymied/ for her published spending figures on federal programs and initiatives related to the [[Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008|2008 bailout]],{{cite web|url=http://openpdf.com/ebook/bailouttallysept2009-pdf-pdf.html |title=Bailout Tally Report by Nomi Prins and Krisztina Ugrin |publisher=Openpdf.com |date=September 2009 |accessdate=2012-06-18}} and for her advocacy for the reinstatement of the [[Glass–Steagall Act]] and regulatory reform of the financial industry. She was also a member of [[Senator Bernie Sanders]] panel of top economic experts to advise on [[Federal Reserve]] reform.https://www.sanders.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/top-economists-to-advise-sanders-on-fed-reform == Personal== Nomi Prins was born in upstate New York, the oldest child in her family. Her father worked for [[IBM]] after having taught at the local college as a Mathematics professor. She received her [[Bachelor degree]] in [[Mathematics]] from [[SUNY Purchase]] with a minor in music and a [[Master in Science]] in [[Statistics]] from [[New York University]].http://www.nomiprins.com/biography/[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OdNOsGFhDb8 Bernie Sanders interviews Nomi Prins] C-SPAN interview from November 16, 2009 ==Career in finance== During her last year, Prins worked part-time at [[Chase Manhattan Bank|Chase Manhattan bank]], which she joined full-time after graduation as an analyst. She subsequently moved to two other firms - [[Bear Stearns]] in [[London]] for seven years and finally at [[Goldman Sachs]] for two years, after which she quit Wall Street.{{cite news|last1=Sanders|first1=Bernie|title=Interview of Nomi Prins by Bernie Sanders|publisher=C-Span2 (Book TV)|date=1 July 2009}} She has presented to numerous venues including the [[Federal Reserve]], [[International Monetary Fund]] and [[World Bank]] Annual conference. There she covered the topic of how to get banks to better serve the real economy.http://pubdocs.worldbank.org/en/487561433784414919/Agenda-15th-International-Conference-on-Policy-Challenges-for-the-Financial-Sector.pdfhttp://www.nomiprins.com/biography/ ==Career as an author== Regarding her book ''It Takes a Pillage'', author [[Jim Hightower]] said, "Nomi Prins knows the mind-set, knows how to read spreadsheets, knows the people, and knows [[Wall Street]]'s games. Nomi knows and now Nomi tells." {{cite web|url=http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0470529598.html |title=It Takes a Pillage: An Epic Tale of Power, Deceit, and Untold Trillions |publisher=Wiley |date= |accessdate=2012-06-18}} Regarding '''''All the Presidents' Bankers''''': * "A calm, authoritative elucidation of verifiable history" — ''[[Financial Times]]'' *"Even those who have read ''Secrets of the Temple'', [[William Greider]]'s massive and brilliant 1987 exposé of the [[Federal Reserve]], will find Prins's book worth their time. She presents a new narrative, one that shows how the changing cast of six has shaped America's fortunes under presidents in both parties." — ''[[American Prospect]]'' *"Prins divides her justifiably long text into digestible one- to three-page segments and seamlessly incorporates dozens of prominent banker profiles. Her work is highly recommended both to general readers and to students of financial history." — ''[[Library Journal]]'' *"A revealing look at the often symbiotic, sometimes-adversarial relationship between the [[White House]] and Wall Street... [A] sweeping history of bank presidents and their relationships with the nation's chief executives" — ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' ==Works== Prins' articles have appeared in ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'', ''[[Newsday]]'', ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'', [[Slate.com]], ''[[The Guardian]]'', ''[[The Nation]]'', ''[[The American Prospect]]'', [[Alternet]], ''[[New York Daily News]]'', ''[[La Vanguardia]]'', and other publications.{{cite web|first=Nomi |last=Prins |url=https://www.motherjones.com/bailout/2009/06/big-bank-bamboozle |title=The Big Bank Bailout Payback Bamboozle |publisher=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] |date=June 14, 2009 |accessdate=2012-06-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thewip.net/contributors/nomi_prins.html |title=The WIP Contributors : Nomi Prins |publisher=The Women's International Perspective |accessdate=2012-06-18}} She is a monthly contributor to Tom Dispatch where she offers analysis on the connections between Wall Street and Washington.{{cite web|title=Tom Dispatch|url=http://www.tomdispatch.com/authors/nomiprins|accessdate=20 April 2017}} Currently, she is working on her latest book that will focus on the movement of money by central banks to influence global markets and economic policy in the domestic and global scale. The Nation Books holds the worldwide English rights to the forthcoming publication.{{cite news|title=The Nation Books|url=http://www.adweek.com/galleycat/nation-books-acquires-nomi-prins-new-book/108959}} ===Books=== *''[https://www.amazon.com/Collusion-Central-Bankers-Rigged-World/dp/1568585624 Collusion]: How Central Bankers Rigged the World'' - Publisher: [[Nation Books]] (5/1/18): {{ISBN|978-1568585628}}. The author claims that central bankers control global markets and dictate economic policy.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Collusion-Central-Bankers-Rigged-World/dp/1568585624}} *''All the Presidents' Bankers: The Hidden Alliances that Drive American Power'' - Publisher: [[Nation Books]] (4/8/14): {{ISBN|978-1568587493}}. *''It Takes a Pillage: Behind the Bonuses, Bailouts, and Backroom Deals from Washington to Wall Street'' - Publisher: [[John Wiley & Sons]] (9/22/09); {{ISBN|0-470-52959-8}}; {{ISBN|978-0-470-52959-1}}. *''Other People's Money: The Corporate Mugging of America'' - Publisher: New Press (8/1/06); {{ISBN|1-59558-063-8}}; {{ISBN|978-1-59558-063-4}}. An account of corporate corruption, political collusion and Wall Street deception. This book was chosen as a Best Book of 2004 by ''[[The Economist]]'', ''[[Barron's (newspaper)|Barron's]]'' and ''[[The Library Journal]]''. *''Jacked: How "Conservatives" are Picking your Pocket (whether you voted for them or not)'' - Publisher: [[Polipoint Press]] (9/1/06); {{ISBN|0-9760621-8-6}}; {{ISBN|978-0-9760621-8-9}}. Catalogs her travels around the USA talking to people about their economic lives.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenation.com/directory/bios/nomi_prins |title=Authors |publisher=[[The Nation]] |date=2012-02-09 |accessdate=2012-06-18}} *''Black Tuesday'' - Publisher: [[CreateSpace]] 2011 - {{ISBN|1-4635-5766-3}}. A historical novel about the [[Crash of 1929]]. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Nomi Prins}} {{external media |video1 = [https://www.pbs.org/wnet/tavissmiley/interviews/writer-nomi-prins/ Video: Tavis Smiley Interviews Journalist Nomi Prins] |video2= [https://www.democracynow.org/2014/4/8/all_the_presidents_bankers_nomi_prins All the Presidents’ Bankers, DemocracyNow!] |video3 = [http://www.demos.org/event_list.cfm?currenteventid=9AC1C3FA-3FF4-6C82-581041A617B73CEA Video: Wall Street's Game, Main Street's Pain] |video4= [http://www.mefeedia.com/watch/24493920 Video: Recovery is not even on horizon] }} *[http://www.nomiprins.com/ Nomi Prins] *[http://www.demos.org/event_list.cfm?currenteventid=9B27BB49-3FF4-6C82-5485A02D101FDD38 Video: Nomi Prins at The Strand, Demos] *{{C-SPAN|Nomi Prins}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Prins, Nomi}} [[Category:American financial analysts]] [[Category:American financial writers]] [[Category:American financial commentators]] [[Category:American alternative journalists]] [[Category:American whistleblowers]] [[Category:Journalists from New York City]] [[Category:Stern School of Business alumni]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Women whistleblowers]]

Quarterbacks coach | highlights = * 2× [[Lone Star Conference|All-LSC]] (1979, 1980) * [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] [[All-American]] (1980) * [[Lone Star Conference|LSC]] MVP (1980) * [[Pro Bowl]] ([[1989 Pro Bowl|1988]]) * [[Super Bowl]] champion ([[Super Bowl XXX|XXX]]) * [[National Football Conference|NFC]] champion ([[1995-96 NFL playoffs|1995]]) * [[List of National Football League season pass completion percentage leaders|NFL completion percentage leader]] (1988) ;as coach * [[National Football Conference|NFC]] champion ([[2006-07 NFL playoffs|2006]]) | statleague = NFL | statlabel1 = TDs–INTs | statvalue1 = 99–102 | statlabel2 = Passing yards | statvalue2 = 17,283 | statlabel3 = Passer rating | statvalue3 = 75.6 | statlabel4 = Attempts | statvalue4 = 2,428 | statlabel5 = Completions | statvalue5 = 1,391 | statlabel6 = Games | statvalue6 = 125 | nflnew = wadewilson/2503760 | regular_record = | playoff_record = | overall_record = | pfr = WilsWa00 | pfrcoach = }} '''Charles Wade Wilson''' (born February 1, 1959) is an [[American football]] coach and former [[quarterback]] who played for the [[Minnesota Vikings]], [[Atlanta Falcons]], [[New Orleans Saints]], [[Dallas Cowboys]] and the [[Oakland Raiders]] in a seventeen-year career from 1981 to 1998 in the [[National Football League]] (NFL). He was [[quarterbacks coach]] for the [[Dallas Cowboys]] from 2000 to 2002 and from 2007 to 2017 and the [[Chicago Bears]] from 2004 to 2006.{{Cite news|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2018/01/03/cowboys-fire-two-veteran-assistant-coaches/|title=Cowboys fire two veteran assistant coaches|date=2018-01-03|work=ProFootballTalk|access-date=2018-01-03|language=en-US}} He played [[college football]] for [[Texas A&M University-Commerce]] (formerly East Texas State University), where he was an NAIA All-American Quarterback and led the Lions to the NAIA national semifinals during the 1980 season. ==Early years== Wilson was born in [[Greenville, Texas]] and lived there shortly, but moved to [[Commerce, Texas]], where he spent most of his childhood. The son of a Coach, Wilson became a standout quarterback and punter at [[Commerce High School (Commerce, Texas)|Commerce High School]]. As a senior, he led the Tigers to a 10-win season and a district championship during his Senior season. He graduated from Commerce High School in 1977. ==College career== ===Freshman Year=== Wilson accepted a football scholarship offer from [[Texas A&M University-Commerce]] (then East Texas State University). His Freshman year in 1977 he backed up Lion All-American Quarterback Terry Skinner. ===Sophomore Year=== Wilson became the starting quarterback for the 1978 season. He completed 69 of 158 pass attempts threw for 770 yards and 3 touchdowns as the Lions finished 4th in Lone Star Conference play with a 4-7 overall record. ===Junior Year=== Wilson's second year as a starter saw dramatic improvement as he completed 150 of 279 pass attempts for 1,826 yards and 10 touchdown passes. The Lions finished the season 5-5, including a 5-2 conference record to finish as LSC runner-up. He was named First Team All-Lone Star Conference and also an [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] All-American. ===Senior Year=== As a senior in 1980, Wilson completed 116 of 227 passes for 1,978 yards and 19 touchdowns, while the Lions finished tied for first with Angelo State among NAIA schools in the Lone Star Conference. The Lions were selected for the NAIA national playoffs as the 8th ranked team in the country. Wilson and the Lions upset at top ranked [[Central Arkansas University]] Bears team in the national quarterfinals, but bowed out to [[Elon College]], the eventual national champion, in the semifinal round. The Lions finished 6th in the country and Wilson was first team All-LSC and First Team NAIA All-American. Wilson graduated in 1981 with a degree in Business Management. He finished his college career with 4,616 passing yards, 32 touchdowns and an 18-14-1 record as a starter. ==Professional career== ===Minnesota Vikings=== Wilson was [[NFL draft|selected]] by the [[Minnesota Vikings]] in the eighth round (210th overall) of the [[1981 NFL Draft]]. He was mostly the backup to [[quarterback]] [[Tommy Kramer]] until 1987, when Kramer started 5 games and Wilson 7 contests, including the playoffs, where the Vikings advanced to the NFC Championship Game after a tremendous upset of the 13-2 [[San Francisco 49ers]] in the Divisional Round, finally succumbing 17-10 to the eventual [[Super Bowl XXII]] champion [[Washington Redskins]]. In 1988, he had a [[Pro Bowl]] season, completing 204 of 332 for 2,746 yards, 15 touchdowns and 9 interceptions. In 1990 and 1991, he shared the quarterback starting position with [[Rich Gannon]]. He was released on July 8, 1992.{{cite web| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19920709&id=JPohAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JaMFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3660,3601068&hl=es | title=Wade Wilson Released By Rebuilding Vikings | accessdate=February 19, 2016}} He finished his Vikings career completing 1,391 passes on 2,428 attempts for 17,283 yards, 99 touchdowns and 102 interceptions. ===Atlanta Falcons=== On July 13, 1992, he was signed as a [[free agent]] by the [[Atlanta Falcons]].{{cite web| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=348&dat=19920714&id=F2YwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GjMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6840,2878959&hl=es | title=Wilson Joins Falcons | accessdate=February 19, 2016}} He appeared in 9 games and started the last three in place of an injured [[Chris Miller (American football)|Chris Miller]], while completing 80 of 114 for 1,1040 yards, 13 touchdowns and 2 interceptions. ===New Orleans Saints=== On April 12, 1993, he signed with the [[New Orleans Saints]], who proceeded to cut former starter [[Bobby Hebert]].{{cite web| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1243&dat=19930413&id=FGcPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=h4YDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1586,5730333&hl=es | title=New Orleans Passes On Hebert, Brings In Wilson | accessdate=February 19, 2016}} He earned the starter job over [[Steve Walsh (American football)|Steve Walsh]] and although he directed the Saints to a 5-0 winning streak, the team only won three more games to finish at 8-8, which would be Wilson's last season as a starter. On March 17, 1994, the team traded a seventh round draft choice in exchange for [[Los Angeles Rams]] [[quarterback]] [[Jim Everett]] and waived Wilson.{{cite web| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1310&dat=19940319&id=4FBWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=q-sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2594,4142325&hl=es | title=Rams unload Everett to New Orleans | accessdate=February 19, 2016}} Wilson was later re-signed and appeared in 4 games. ===Dallas Cowboys=== On May 22, 1995, he was signed by the [[Dallas Cowboys]] to be the backup [[quarterback]] to [[Troy Aikman]].{{cite web| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1298&dat=19950523&id=gv4yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vwcGAAAAIBAJ&pg=3874,4433893&hl=es | title=Dallas Signs Wade Wilson As Backup Quarterback | accessdate=February 19, 2016}} He was a part of the [[Super Bowl XXX]] winning team. He only started one game during his three seasons with the Cowboys, when the team played its backups in the 1996 season finale against the [[Washington Redskins]], a 10-37 loss. ===Oakland Raiders=== On July 6, 1998, he signed with the [[Oakland Raiders]] to be the third-string quarterback, although he was later named the backup and even started 3 games in place of [[Jeff George]] during the season.{{cite web| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1310&dat=19980707&id=Qd1YAAAAIBAJ&sjid=resDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1994,1784319&hl=es | title=Wilson Signs Deal With The Raiders | accessdate=February 19, 2016}} In 1999, the [[Oakland Raiders]] signed [[Rich Gannon]] and Wilson became the third-string [[quarterback]].{{cite web| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2457&dat=19990216&id=dwxbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=P04NAAAAIBAJ&pg=4582,196264&hl=es | title=Raiders Sign Gannon As Starter | accessdate=February 19, 2016}} He retired at the age of 40 in 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.profootballhof.com/football-history/40-and-over-club/|title=History: Players Who've Played in NFL at Age 40 or Older|work=[[Pro Football Hall of Fame]]|accessdate=2015-12-01}} ==Coaching career== Wilson was the [[Chicago Bears]] quarterback [[Coach (sport)|coach]] from [[2004 NFL season|2004]] until [[2006 NFL season|2006]], while reaching [[Super Bowl XLI]]. On February 22, [[2007 NFL season|2007]], he re-signed with the Cowboys, for whom he was the quarterback coach from [[2000 NFL season|2000]] to [[2002 NFL season|2002]].{{cite news|url=http://www.suntimes.com/sports/football/bears/269660,CST-SPT-wade23.article |work=Chicago Sun-Times |title=Chicago - Chicago : News : Politics : Things To Do : Sports |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070306001405/http://www.suntimes.com/sports/football/bears/269660%2CCST-SPT-wade23.article |archivedate=March 6, 2007 }} On September 1, [[2007 NFL season|2007]], Wilson was suspended five games and fined $100,000 for purchasing and using performance-enhancing drugs.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/nfl/news/story?id=3019472 |title=ESPN - Dallas assistant wants Goodell to explain Belichick's punishment - NFL |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date=2007-09-14 |accessdate=2015-09-28}} In his defense, Wilson has said that the drug ([[HGH]]) was used to help his problem with [[diabetes]]. However, Commissioner [[Roger Goodell|Goodell]] seemed to sidestep this defense saying, "First of all, I'm not going to get into the personal situations of why Wade was taking it, but that's not an accurate point."{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/football/cowboys/stories/091707dnspocowsider2.33da1bb.html |title=Goodell says Wilson's punishment is justified | Dallas Cowboys News | Sports News | News for Dallas, Texas | Dallas Morning News |publisher=Dallasnews.com |date=2007-09-17 |accessdate=2010-09-28}} ==Personal life== Wilson has four children, Travis Wade, Hayden, and twins Coleton and Sophie. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Footballstats |nfl=WIL662355 |espn=5 |yahoo=30 |si=30 |pfr=W/WilsWa00 }} {{Vikings1981DraftPicks}} {{Minnesota Vikings starting quarterback navbox}} {{Atlanta Falcons starting quarterback navbox}} {{New Orleans Saints starting quarterback navbox}} {{Oakland Raiders starting quarterback navbox}} {{Dallas Cowboys starting quarterback navbox}} {{Super Bowl XXX}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wilson, Wade}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Atlanta Falcons players]] [[Category:Chicago Bears coaches]] [[Category:Dallas Cowboys coaches]] [[Category:Dallas Cowboys players]] [[Category:Minnesota Vikings players]] [[Category:National Conference Pro Bowl players]] [[Category:American football quarterbacks]] [[Category:New Orleans Saints players]] [[Category:Oakland Raiders players]] [[Category:People from Greenville, Texas]] [[Category:People with diabetes mellitus type 1]] [[Category:Players of American football from Texas]] [[Category:Texas A&M–Commerce Lions football players]] [[Category:Super Bowl champions]] [[Category:People from Commerce, Texas]]
